This PR creates separate targets for running the examples and validates them with existing output in `doc/results.dox`.

author: Yuhsiang M. Tsai
message:
Merge add absolute function, complex/real converter on class

This PR adds the absolute (inplace/outplace) of the matrix and complex<-> real on class

Summary
- add `to_complex` and to_real as remove_complex alias
- make `to_complex/real` and `remove_complex` work for class or scalar/complex
Note. Can not use `remove_complex<class>` as friend class. Need to use `class<remove_complex<V>, I>`. this type helper should work in the other situation.
- add `inplace_absolute_array` and `outplace_absolute_array`
- `format->compute_absolute_inplace()` is inplace absolute function
- `auto result = format->compute_absolute()` is outplace absolute function: format -> remove_complex<format>
- Add `AbsoluteComputable` interface and `compute_absolute_linop` can be used with LinOp.
- After this PR, need /bigobj for all MSVC.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/636

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
Merge fix for add_subdirectory builds for Ginkgo

This PR removes all uses of absolute CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR/BINARY_DIR variables in favor of the relative
PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR/BINARY_DIR, which now makes Ginkgo work as an add_subdirectory build.
This behavior is also tested in a new CI step, and all remaining traces of twentyseven-point-stencil are removed.
Note that GINKGO_DEVEL_TOOLS does not work due to git-cmake-format being stored in the build directory
and using `git rev-parse` on the top-level directory.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/641

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
fix add_subdirectory builds for Ginkgo

Currently, we often use CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR instead of the
preferred PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR (relative to the last project() call)
or CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR (relative to the current CMakeLists.txt)

This causes issues when Ginkgo is built as a subdirectory instead
of installing it.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Release 1.3.0 for develop

Release 1.3.0 of Ginkgo.

The Ginkgo team is proud to announce the new minor release of Ginkgo version
1.3.0. This release brings CUDA 11 support, changes the default C++ standard to
be C++14 instead of C++11, adds a new Diagonal matrix format and capacity for
diagonal extraction, significantly improves the CMake configuration output
format, adds the Ginkgo paper which got accepted into the Journal of Open Source
Software (JOSS), and fixes multiple issues.

Supported systems and requirements:
+ For all platforms, cmake 3.9+
+ Linux and MacOS
  + gcc: 5.3+, 6.3+, 7.3+, all versions after 8.1+
  + clang: 3.9+
  + Intel compiler: 2017+
  + Apple LLVM: 8.0+
  + CUDA module: CUDA 9.0+
  + HIP module: ROCm 2.8+
+ Windows
  + MinGW and Cygwin: gcc 5.3+, 6.3+, 7.3+, all versions after 8.1+
  + Microsoft Visual Studio: VS 2017 15.7+
  + CUDA module: CUDA 9.0+, Microsoft Visual Studio
  + OpenMP module: MinGW or Cygwin.


The current known issues can be found in the [known issues page](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/wiki/Known-Issues).


Additions:
+ Add paper for Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS). [#479](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/479)
+ Add a DiagonalExtractable interface. [#563](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/563)
+ Add a new diagonal Matrix Format. [#580](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/580)
+ Add Cuda11 support. [#603](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/603)
+ Add information output after CMake configuration. [#610](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/610)
+ Add a new preconditioner export example. [#595](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/595)
+ Add a new cuda-memcheck CI job. [#592](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/592)

Changes:
+ Use unified memory in CUDA debug builds. [#621](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/621)
+ Improve `BENCHMARKING.md` with more detailed info. [#619](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/619)
+ Use C++14 standard instead of C++11. [#611](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/611)
+ Update the Ampere sm information and CudaArchitectureSelector. [#588](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/588)

Fixes:
+ Fix documentation warnings and errors. [#624](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/624)
+ Fix warnings for diagonal matrix format. [#622](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/622)
+ Fix criterion factory parameters in CUDA. [#586](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/586)
+ Fix the norm-type in the examples. [#612](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/612)
+ Fix the WAW race in OpenMP is_sorted_by_column_index. [#617](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/617)
+ Fix the example's exec_map by creating the executor only if requested. [#602](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/602)
+ Fix some CMake warnings. [#614](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/614)
+ Fix Windows building documentation. [#601](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/601)
+ Warn when CXX and CUDA host compiler do not match. [#607](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/607)
+ Fix reduce_add, prefix_sum, and doc-build. [#593](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/593)
+ Fix find_library(cublas) issue on machines installing multiple cuda. [#591](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/591)
+ Fix allocator in sellp read. [#589](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/589)
+ Fix the CAS with HIP and NVIDIA backends. [#585](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/585)

Deletions:
+ Remove unused preconditioner parameter in LowerTrs. [#587](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/587)

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/625

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Fix documentation warnings and errors.

Fix some issues with the documentation, esp. after the recent changes.

The main issue is triggered by the filter which replaces the `$` signs (even in source code!) into doxygen's `@f$` which is interpreted as inline math. On top of it, multiple warnings are fixed.

Details:
+ Apply the filter only to specific file patterns. Replacing all `$`
  characters by `@f$` creates a big issue in bash and other languages
  where `$` has another signification. This convenience feature is needed
  only for the hpp/cpp/cu* files.
+ Remove the `FILE_VERSION_FILTER` from the Doxyfile configuration: this
  command is used to extract the version of every file and is always ran.
  We already publish the version of Ginkgo so it's unneeded. In addition,
  when building out of source, the example files are not part of a git
  repository and that creates issues.
+ Remove the `doxygen_image_path` as it's unused and throws a warning
+ Use `Ginkgo_SOURCE_DIR` to locate the md files instead of `../..`.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/624

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Improve `BENCHMARKING.md` with more detailed info.

Adds more detailed information on how to benchmark Ginkgo.

Thanks Adam Jacobs for his useful review process for the JOSS paper which pointed to a lack of documentation on how to benchmark Ginkgo.

Summary:
+ Detail a bit how to use `ssget` and what to watch out for.
+ Add a benchmark overview section with the most important options.
+ Optionally detail a little how to interact with the GPE after obtaining benchmark results as well as what to watch out for.
+ Detail a little how to obtain more detailed information as well as how to debug Ginkgo through loggers.
+ Update the available options in the script.
+ In addition, I try to change the way we generate the `run_all_benchmarks.sh` script in order to give the proper rights to this file by default (execution `x` access).

Related issue: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/597
Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/619

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
Merge fix for criterion factory parameters and CUDA

Due to a bug in nvcc, it was previously impossible to use the with_... literate interface for factory parameters in CUDA.
This PR contains a workaround for this bug that works by distinguishing between primitive type factory parameters,
for which we cannot use parameter pack expansion to initialize them from an arbitrary number of arguments,
and composite factory parameters, for which we can.
The old factory parameter interface is left in place to ensure interface compatibility with people using it in their factories.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/586

message:
fix GKO_FACTORY_PARAMETER for CUDA

nvcc has issues with parameter pack expansion
assigned to primitive-type variables.

This can be worked around with a backward-compatible
interface by adding _SCALAR and _VECTOR "overloads"
and deprecating the plain GKO_FACTORY_PARAMETER

author: fritzgoebel
message:
Merge Diagonal Matrix Format

Introduces a new diagonal matrix format.
The new format can be applied to dense and csr matrices, both from the left (apply) and from the right (rapply) side.
Applying a diagonal matrix to A from the left scales A's rows, applying it from the right scales A's columns.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/580

author: Yuhsiang M. Tsai
message:
Merge Add Cuda11 support

This PR mainly makes ginkgo be able to run with cuda11

Summary:
1. add generic spmv/spmm into cusparse spmv/spmm
2. use cusp_coo/cusp_csr as cusp_gcoo/cusp_gcsr in benchmark/spmv
3. use correct architecture flag in cuda/test
4. use cuda11's cooperative group because it supports complex shuffle, but we remove the parent type in `tiled_partition`
5. add cuda 10.2/11 gitlab ci (linux) and cuda11 github action (windows)
6. replace deprecated `spgemm2` and `gthr` by new cusparse generic interface.

Note. it works for cuda11 release not release candidate because shuffle in cuda11rc does not really support complex type.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/603

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Use C++14 standard instead of C++11

There are multiple reasons for this:
1. CUDA's thrust will be deprecating C++11 and moving to C++14 shortly. 
2. On paper and in practice, all the compiler versions we support already support C++14, so moving doesn't make us lose anything. The only failure is a corner case of CUDA 9.2 and clang 5.0 as CUDA host compiler which cannot be fixed, see the comments in the related PR on this issue.

What changed:
+ Upgrade any mention of C++11 to C++14
+ Review the `std_extensions` to use implementation from C++14 instead of the custom made one.
+ Update all code calls from `xstd` to `std` when the feature used was a C++14 feature.
+ Use Intel 2020 together with GCC 9 as there is an incompatibility when considering C++14 between Intel 2019 and GCC 9.
+ Ensure tests are always compiled with the C++14 standard
+ Throw a fatal_error when using CUDA 9.2 with clang 5.0 as CUDA host compiler.

Closes: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/604
Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/611

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
Merge Clean up sanitizers

This PR gets rid of unnecessary sanitizer warnings and fixes the remaining issues:

* All sanitizers complain about the huge allocations we do in our executor tests.
  This can be solved by allowing allocators to return null.
* UBSAN complains about empty memcpys on nullptrs.
  This can be solved by only memcpy-ing non-empty data
* TSAN complains about some write-after-write data races in the stopping conditions.
  This is not an issue, since we always write the same value, but it can be mitigated by
  making the for-loop a reduction
* TSAN complains about another write-after-write data race in bicgstab,
  where we do some unnecessarily duplicate work in parallel.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/581

author: tcojean
message:
Merge HIP Clang compatibility

Make Ginkgo compatible with HIP Clang compilation.

hip-clang actually fixes some of the most horrible thing with the classical
`hcc` compiler, in particular it's not necessary to ban the privous flags
anymore because all of these were `hcc` related. On the other end, some
new flags need to be banned from the hip::device target which are
explicitely hip-clang related.

+ Add the new option to pass in HIP clang specific options
+ Properly detect and populate the new critical ROCM_PATH and
  HIP_CLANG_PATH variables.
+ Make HIP THRUST easier to be found thanks to using an optional environment variable.
+ Also add some missing test for the HipError and related classes
+ Also fix some missing includes which were found
+ Find the HIP version and use a different scheme between 3.5 and after
which allow options and lesser than 3.5 which do not allow clang options.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/567

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
Merge fix for benchmark logger crashes with OpenMP

This fixes potential race conditions in the benchmark operation loggers due to multiple
OpenMP threads (de)allocating data at the same time, by ensuring mutual exclusion (std::mutex).

The Jacobi and spgemm kernels may still call allocation, copy and free from multiple threads,
which can cause invalid operation timings for OpenMP.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/565

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
prevent benchmark logger crashes with OpenMP

Some OpenMP algorithms may call executor operations (alloc and free)
from multiple threads, which can crash the loggers.

This fixes these race conditions by ensuring exclusive access.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Fix the automatical strategy when shared.

Use a copy function and rewrite some tests.

The automatical strategy has an issue when shared, it behaves as the
wrong strategy if the matrices using it have different properties.
This fixes this issue only by extending the current interface, and not
changing any existing function. All other (more elegant) approaches
I thought of would break the current interface. In effect:
+ Add a new virtual `copy` function to the strategies in order to create
  a new shared pointer polymorphically.
+ The approach used is to always copy the strategy, whenever a CSR
  matrix is instantiated or copied. Thankfully, the strategies are
  currently light objects so this should create few overhead.
+ Add tests which ensure that matrices with difference properties work
  correctly with the automatical strategy.

Fixes https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/426
Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/559

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Fix the automatical strategy when shared.

The automatical strategy has an issue when shared, it behaves as the
wrong strategy if the matrices using it have different properties.
This fixes this issue only by extending the current interface, and not
changing any existing function. In effect:
+ Add a new virtual `copy` function to the strategies in order to create
  a new shared pointer polymorphically.
+ The approach used is to always copy the strategy, whenever a CSR
  matrix is instantiated or copied. Thankfully, the strategies are
  currently light objects so this should create few overhead.
+ Add tests which ensure that matrices with difference properties work
  correctly with the automatical strategy.

Fixes https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/426

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Fix the (cuda|hip)DeviceReset issue.

Add a boolean class to control the DeviceReset.

By default, the device is not reset.

All examples, benchmarks and the last executors from the tests are
modified to pass the correct value to reset the device after use. This
ensures that our CI tools and users can keep tracking memory leaks
internally.

Fixes issue: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/461
Relater PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/557

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Fix the (cuda|hip)DeviceReset issue.

To fix this problem, an optional boolean class is added which controls
whether to reset or not the device controlled by the executor. By
default, the device is not reset.

All examples, benchmarks and the last executors from the tests are
modified to pass the correct value to reset the device after use. This
ensures that our CI tools and users can keep tracking memory leaks
internally.

Fixes: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/461

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Add editorconfig support

Add editorconfig support for better code style.

This does two things mainly:
+ Add support for editorconfig, see https://editorconfig.org/.
  + This is basically a specific configuration file for the project which tells editors what to do in terms of indentation for which file. This should be natively supported by visual studio, and plugins exist for vim and emacs, among other editors.
  + The configuration added uses utf-8 for all files, 4 spaces indentation for everything except `.md` and `.yml` files which already use 2 spaces indentation, and I feel that style to be fitting with these formats. Changing these styles would also add a lot of useless line changes. Maybe we can discuss that in the future whenever some significant change is done to the CI setup.
+ When files were found to not abide to the indentation rules (with a dumb grep command), in particular for CMake files, they were properly indented. CMake has been a long standing issue in terms of formatting since clang-format takes care of most of the other files. So far, we were trying to use 4 space indent also in CMake, but inconsistencies appeared since some editors (e.g. emacs) use 2 space by default. The editorconfig tool can fill the holes such as in the CMake case.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/546

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
Merge ParILUT

This adds parallel threshold incomplete LU and Cholesky preconditioners to Ginkgo

The factorization generation consists of
* spgemm to compute the current approximation L*U/L*L^T
* candidate addition (three-way spgeam where one sparsity pattern is the subset of another)
* parallel sweep ("asynchronous" iteration for updating the values of the factorization)
* threshold selection and filtering (removing a specified fraction of the smallest elements)
* a few auxiliary kernels like sparse matrix transposition, conversion CSR->COO etc.

Some additional changes:
* add __forceinline__ to some small GPU kernels
* add special treatment for diagonal in ILU initialization kernels again
* output matrix contents in tests only for small matrices, store them to disk for larger ones
* log iteration timestamps for solver benchmarks

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/400

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Disable CI for the private repository

There are two contributions in this PR: 
1. Disable the CI for the private repository,
2. Fix the parallelism issues introduced by the load limit argument given to ninja.

### Disable CI for the private repository
Disable the CI for the private repository in order to remove the now lengthy redundant jobs.

This is done by using a variable acting as a tag to specify if the CI should be run or not. By default, on the public CI repository that tag is set, hence all jobs are always ran. For the private repository, no jobs will be ran by default, except for the `sync` job for the master or develop branches.
To run jobs on the private CI, one needs to explicitly create a new pipeline and pass in as variable `RUN_CI_TAG = 1`.

To ensure it works, I pushed a commit on the private repository, which you can find [here](https://gitlab.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/-/commit/ee1a936b23aae6a5723946792f6c9ac148a9550f). As you can see, no CI was ran for this commit.

### Parallelism and load limit fix
This is done by using two new environment variables:

+ `CI_PARALLELISM`, the number of cores available per CI job.
+ `CI_LOAD_LIMIT`, the maximum authorized load limit (total number of
   cores on the machine).

Both of these are set in the respective /etc/gitlab-runner/config.toml
for each machine, in the `[[runners]]` section. See:
https://docs.gitlab.com/runner/configuration/advanced-configuration.html#the-runners-section

### Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/539

author: Matthias Maier
message:
Add a SONAME to shared libraries

Ginkgo is written in C++ and does not guarantee any stable ABI.
Consequently, all shared libraries should be annotated by an appropriate
SONAME (this patch simply uses the release version). This ensures
conformity with best practices and library requirements for popular
Linux distributions (e.g., Debian/Ubuntu). It also prevents silent
breakage (at dynamic link time / run time) when the library ABI changed
and user code should have been recompiled.

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
Merge support for arbitrary row-lengths in GPU ISAI

This PR removes the row size limit in GPU ISAI by turning overly long rows into sparse blocks
of a triangular system that is solved separately.

Additionally, it contains a few other small improvements:
* remove unnecessary identity_triangle kernel, since we only need the sparsity pattern
of L^k, the values will be overwritten anyways
* rewrite GPU ISAI kernels so they don't need to transpose the local sparse system
* uses a *square-and-multiply* algorithm instead of the naive approach for ISAI(k)
* fixes an off-by-one error in the gdb pretty-printer
* ensures that CSR `row_ptrs` are never empty
* renames `isfinite` to `is_finite`

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/520

author: Yuhsiang M. Tsai
message:
Merge Reorder krylov bases of gmres

This PR reorders the Krylov bases of gmres and does some improvement

Ki = the i-th vector of Krylov basis for each rhs
K = [K1 K2 ... Kn], which lead the stride of Krylov still be larger than 1 even if the num_rhs = 1.
use K = [K1; K2; ...; Kn] to get coalesced memory access when num_rhs = 1
Also, use the vendor's dot function when num_rhs = 1.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/523

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Allow benchmarking from a matrix list file

This adds more option to the `run_all_benchmarks.sh` script in order to be more practical.

In particular:
+ A new variable is added, `MATRIX_LIST_FILE` which can be set to a file containing a list of suitesparse matrices (one per line) to allow more targeted benchmarking. Either the ID, the name, or `group/name` form can be used to identify the matrix. As an example, the following list would be valid to benchmark the matrices for the TOMS interface paper:
  ```
    1903
    Freescale/circuit5M
    rajat31
    Freescale/FullChip
    Bodendiek/CurlCurl_4
    Janna/Bump_2911
    Janna/Cube_Coup_dt0
    Janna/StocF-1465
    Bourchtein/atmosmodj
    thermal2
  ```
+ Options are added to configure the solvers and matrix formats to use
+ Options are added to configure tolerance and maximum number of iterations for solvers
+ Options are added to run detailed solver benchmarks or not (the detailed default is now set to off as part of the script, though the runner still has the detailed default set to true, what is the best setting for this? It's a lot of overkill information)

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/503

author: fritzgoebel
message:
Merge pull request #506 from ginkgo-project/ilu_pteconditioner_assure_linearity

This vector copy ensures linearity of the preconditioner when iterative solvers are used for the triangular systems.

Without the additional copy, the solution vector is used as initial guess to the second solver, no matter its content. When only doing a few iterations, this initial guess still has a strong influence on the result and, depending what is in the respective initial guess vecotrs, we cannot assume the following equality:
prec(x_1) + prec(x_2) = prec(x_1 + x_2)

(here, prec(x) means applying the preconditioner to a vector x)

Especially for preconditioned GMRES, this leads to errors in the result.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/506

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Simple overhead benchmarking facilities

Add simple overhead benchmarking facilities by modifying the `solver` benchmarks with:
+ A new `overhead` boolean parameter to ask whether or not an overhead benchmark should be done. This will use a simple matrix with a single `1.0` `value,` `0.0` as `x`, and `nan` as `b` (same setup as the `ginkgo_overhead` example). 
+ A new `Overhead` LinOP which does a normal solver setup in terms of Factory parameters and generation, except that it has an `apply_impl` method which calls four empty kernels. We have multiple runtime polymorphism calls which come into play here. I am most likely forgetting many of them: 
    + generate,
    + apply,
    + system_matrix and preconditioner's apply,
    + four kernel calls (`run()` functions), ...
+ This `Overhead` LinOp can be also be used as a preconditioner.

This allows the following:
+ Benchmark any solver/preconditioner with the dummy data.
+ Benchmark the overhead LinOp (optionally with preconditioner) with the dummy data.

### Example of results
We get the following results currently, benchmarked on BW Unicluster with 10.000 iterations:
+ CG with dummy data,
   + generate: `0.829 us`,
   + apply (1000 iterations): `1277.557 us`.
   + apply (2000 iterations) - apply (1000 iterations): `1200.118 us`
+ bicgstab with dummy data,
   + generate: `0.814 us`,
   + apply (1000 iterations): `1259.751 us`.
   + apply (2000 iterations) - apply (1000 iterations): `1239.370 us`
+ fcg with dummy data,
   + generate: `0.837 us`,
   + apply (1000 iterations): `1447.981 us`.
   + apply (2000 iterations) - apply (1000 iterations): `1410.630 us`
+ cgs with dummy data,
   + generate: `0.849 us`,
   + apply (1000 iterations): `1001.975 us`.
   + apply (2000 iterations) - apply (1000 iterations): `881.990 us`
+ gmres with dummy data,
   + generate: `0.836 us`,
   + apply (1000 iterations): `1510.327 us`.
   + apply (2000 iterations) - apply (1000 iterations): `1485.361 us`
+ Overhead "solver" with dummy data,
   + generate: `0.788 us`,
   + apply: `0.912 us`.
+ Overhead "solver" with overhead "preconditioner" with dummy data:
   + generate: `1.479 us`,
   + apply: `2.610 us`.

### Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/501

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Update Ginkgo to the new containers status.

This updates the containers usage in our main repository due to some changes made while developing the automatic container building system which is available there for project members: https://gitlab.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo-containers

Example of automatic build pipeline: https://gitlab.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo-containers/pipelines/133883673

### Summary of this PR's changes
+ Intel support has been made clear in container names
+ A repository stores all the containers and more, so remove them from Ginkgo
  itself.
+ Intel 2017 is already in CUDA 9.2 image, so do not use it in 9.1.
+ Image names are fixed for new llvm scheme from 7 onward, there is no ".0"
+ The old nocuda with gnu 8 image is useless now that we have proper tags for
  requesting an Intel capable image (on the CUDA machine).

### Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/499

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge fix for dim

This PR introduces a simple fix to gko::dim.
Previously, it relied on the binary representation to work properly,
and the intel compiler also sometimes optimized away the copying of
some non-first dimensions. Now, it should properly comply with the C++
standard (without relying on a specific binary representation).
Additionally, two tests were added.


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/498

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Fix the view memory leak and array/view copy/move.

This fixes some of the discussed issues with arrays. The changes are noted in the list below. Some of these points should still be discussed.

+ Add tests for copy/move of all combinations of array/view.
+ Add a new exception helper macro for testing array dimensions.
+ When copying something into a view, do bound checking and ensure what is
  copied has a compatible amount of data.
+ When copying into an array, the proper amount of data is allocated and copied
   over.
+ When moving a into b, b becomes a and a is invalid afterwards.
+ Resize and reset for views throws an error.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/485

author: fritzgoebel
message:
Merge: Change how GMRES handles preconditioned vector

This PR changes the way GMRES handles the precoditioned vector.

Introduced changes:
- in `initialize_2`, `next_krylov_basis` gets initialized with the normalized residual
- instead of creating `preconditioned_vector` as a submatrix of `krylov_bases` where it got the same padding as `krylov_bases` and applying the preconditioner to this, the preconditioner now gets applied to `next_krylov_basis`. This makes it possible to use the cuda implementation of GMRES with the default spmv strategy which does not support padded vectors

Related PR: #481

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Replace valgrind by all sanitizers available.

This removes valgrind and instead adds leak sanitizer, memory sanitizer and undefined behavior sanitizer checks. The hope is to gain quite a CI speedup without losing in quality checks (in fact, UBsan could find new important issues).

+ Add a new UBSAN configuration for undefined behavior.
+ Add a new leak sanitizer configuration.
+ Add a sanitizers test to ensure all sanitizers work.
+ Add a new ginkgo_create_thread_test helper for the sanitizers test.
+ Add CI steps to check for leaks and undefined behavior.

Also update containers with various fixes and additions:
+ Add Metis build option
+ Add MPI build option
+ Make CUDA 10.1 to be based on ubuntu 18.04
+ Fix an issue with HIP and CUDA <= 9.1
+ Disable HIP and CUDA builds with coverage since this is not supported

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Add core and reference multiprecision tests

This adds multiprecision tests for the core and reference modules. In addition to this, all non matrix, solver and preconditioners in the OpenMP module also have multiprecision tests.
### Summary of changes
+ All core tests rewrote for multiple precisions
+ All reference tests rewrote for multiple precisions
+ Extra OpenMP tests rewrote for multiple precisions (non matrix, solver or preconditioner).
+ codecov is put back into Ginkgo, and our coverage significantly improved thanks to the templated tests
+ In `core/test/utils.hpp`, a bunch of declarations were provided for default values we want to tests, and other tools used when doing multiprecision tests.
+ In `core/test/utils/assertions.hpp`, `get_relative_error` and other commonly used functions from the assertions were extended for the complex value case (using `gko::remove_complex` most of the time). A new assertion was added for comparing values of complex type (`GKO_ASSERT_NEAR`, which extends the basic gtest one `ASSERT_NEAR`).
+ Papi required some fixes (counting the instances of Papi loggers globally instead of per template valuetype).
+ `Ilu` required some fixes (using `gko::remove_complex` and removing default valuetype use of `<>`).

### How to write templated tests
`core/tests/utils.hpp` always needs to be included because it provides required definitions.
In general, if only one kind of precision (e.g. `value_type`) is required, then normal templating can be used, otherwise, due to the use of the macro for declaring the templated values to try, a tuple which contains all the elements need to be defined, see the `reference/test/matrix/csr_kernels.cpp` for example.
```cpp
template <typename ValueIndexType>
class Csr : public ::testing::Test {
protected:
    using value_type =
        typename std::tuple_element<0, decltype(ValueIndexType())>::type;
    using index_type =
        typename std::tuple_element<1, decltype(ValueIndexType())>::type;
};
```

Afterwards, the class needs to be instantiated for all precisions, which is done such as in the following way:
```cpp
TYPED_TEST_CASE(Csr, gko::test::ValueIndexTypes);
```
Note that `ValueIndexTypes` is provided by `utils.hpp` and contains tuples of all valuetype and index type combinations.

As a requirement, the tests now need to use the macro `TYPED_TEST` instead of `TEST_F`. This has multiple implications:
+ All member objects/functions have to be accessed with `this->`.
+ All member definitions such as `using` need to be accessed through `TestFixture::Mtx` for example. The approach I used is to add to every test the required `using` shortcut to make the tests look nicer.
+ A variable `TypeParam` is provided which is the template type of the test.
+ Due to complexes being able to be built with `{real, img}` notation, our initializations of the form `{{1.0, 2.0}, {3.0, 4.0}}` are ambiguous (the second `{`). I provided a shortcut `I<type>` for stating that this is actually an initializer list of type T, and not a complex construction. So the following example would be replaced with:  
```cpp
using T = typename TestFixture::value_type;
auto mtx = gko::initialize({I<T>{1.0, 2.0}, I<T>{3.0, 4.0}}, this->exec);
```

Finally, I implemented a shortcut `r<value_type>::value` for providing depending on the type of the value a proper precision (`1e-7` for `float` and `std::complex<float>`, and `1e-14` for `double` variants).


### Closes: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/32
### Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/448

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Improve isfinite function and the test for it

`isFinite()` was previously hand-implemented with a bit-mask since it
seemed to be the least amount of work. However, the PTX code that
`isfinite(x)` produces does `abs(x) < INF`.
Now, that is also what the hand-written implementation does.
Tests were also adjusted to always cover the hand-written
implmenentation as well as the `gko::isfinite()`.

author: Thomas Grützmacher

Merge Fix to ParILU by adding explicit zeros to diagonal

This PR adds the kernel `add_diagonal_elements` to `ParIlu` which adds
explicit zeros to the main diagonal if such element was not already
present.
This ensures that both `L` and `U` are always properly updated during
the generation.


Related issue: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/455

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge adding CUDA header dependency to appropriate tests

We included `cuda.h` in the tests for the solvers `LowerTrs` and
`UpperTrs` without stating that these tests need CUDA header.
As a result, the current code does not compile on some systems.

This PR adds `CUDA_INCLUDE_DIRS` as include directories for these
two tests, so `cuda.h` is always found.
Additionally, `cuda.h` is now also included in
`cuda/components/atomics.cuh` since we need access to the macro
`CUDA_VERSION` there.


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/452
            https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/451

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
Extract prefix sum computations

This PR introduces a new prefix_sum kernel that is used instead of manually computing prefix sums in different places. This also fixes two bugs:

* In CUDA/HIP ParILU, the wrong num_blocks is used for launching the prefix sum kernels
* In Reference ParILU, the handling of non-existent diagonals during initialization is incorrect.

Finally, it removes a few unnecessary calls to Array::clear since they would be cleaned up via RAII anyways.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/429

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
Disable GINKGO_DEVEL_TOOLS by default

This PR sets the default for GINKGO_DEVEL_TOOLS to OFF to make it easier for users to use our library even though they don't have the necessary tools (especially clang-format) installed.

To not break our workflow, it adds a dummy pre-commit hook that is installed when DEVEL_TOOLS is off and rejects every commit with a reminder message. The hook is not installed when the git-cmake-format hook is already present.

Closes https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/440

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/442

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge adding strategy setting factory parameter for ParIlu

This PR adds the possibility to specify the strategy that will be used
for L and U as a factory parameter in the factorization ParIlu.
Previously, the strategy `sparselib` was always used, which cannot
handle multiple right hand sides. Now, the default strategy is
`classical`, which can handle multiple right hand sides.
It can also be changed through the mentioned factory parameter.


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/427

Add HIP bindings for SpGeMM

This PR adds HIP bindings for simple SpGeMM (C = alpha * A * B).
The full SpGeMM (C = alpha * A * B + beta * D) is not yet implemented in rocSPARSE, so I re-implemented it using a very naive SpGeAM kernel. Note that it assumes that the input matrices are sorted!

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/418

This PR makes `Dense::create_with_config_of` to call a virtual

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
Improve portability of warp lane masks

This commit adds a `lane_mask_type` type alias to the `config` struct for CUDA and HIP kernels.
It additionally provides overloads for the `popc`, `ffs` and `clz` intrinsics that are often used in conjunction with these lane masks, so they can be called portably for all architectures.
Warp lane masks are the result of the ballot vote functions and can be important for warp-aggregation (with or without atomics).

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/422

author: Tobias Ribizel

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
Add bitonic sorting kernels

This adds a three-stage bitonic sorting implementation for GPUs:

* In the first stage, a power-of-two number of elements are being sorted locally within each thread
* In the second stage, these local elements are being sorted within a warp/wavefront using butterfly shuffles
* In the third stage, these elements from a power-of-two number of warps/wavefronts are being sorted using shared memory.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/417

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Compile HIP related code only once in CI.

Use a workaround for not having two HIP compilation in CI jobs.

The workaround is to not give CMake the chance to have a second build! This is the only way to do this AFAIK, since due to how HIP is built, the code will always be entirely compiled two successive times if given the chance, after which things settle down and only changed files are recompiled from the third time on. 

### Improvements in practice
Before: [92 minutes](https://gitlab.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo-public-ci/-/jobs/377695917)
After: [69 minutes](https://gitlab.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo-public-ci/-/jobs/377884828)

### Explanation of the two compilations issue
The two compilations happen due to the way HIP manages its compilations and dependencies. The problem was the same when using `FindCUDA.cmake` through CMake at some point. `FindHIP.cmake` provides macros which automatically do the HIP code compilation, including separate host and device compilation. 
As part of this process, for every file HIP needs to generate a dependency file such as `ginkgo_hip_generated_par_ilu_kernels.hip.cpp.o.depend` which contains every single header and other file that this file in question uses. The use of this is that when any dependency listed in this list changes, the targeted file has to be recompiled.

The problem is that with the way things are, there is no way to have this list at CMake configuration time, so this list is built at "build time" (first `make`). What happens then is that the second time the project is built, CMake sees this new dependency file which did not exist before (i.e. was considered empty I guess), and therefore CMake has to rebuild all the related files during the second `make`, since to it all the dependencies of the file changed. Every subsequent compilations (from the third `make` on) will work as expected, with rebuilds happening only for files which really changed.

### Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/421

author: Terry Cojean

Use a workaround for not having two HIP compilation in CI jobs.

Do not give CMake the chance to have a second build!

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Fix GinkgoTargets.cmake with the correct installation paths

This fixes Ginkgo's installation step as it is currently wrong.

### Description of the problem being fixed
With the current setup, on installation all paths in the target's properties populated in the `GinkgoTargets.cmake` are of the form: 
    + `INTERFACE_INCLUDE_DIRECTORIES "/path/to/build/dir/include;/path/to/source/dir/include;/path/to/source/dir"`,
    + `IMPORTED_LOCATION_RELEASE "/path/to/build/dir/cuda/libginkgo_cuda.so"`,
    + This is later copied into the installation directory, which is wrong.

After this PR, we still have the `GinkgoTargets.cmake` in the build directory with such paths, (in case we expose the CMake the build directory as a usable CMake package, this is a Ginkgo option), **but on installation a new one is generated** with the the proper paths instead. For example, we now find:
    + `INTERFACE_INCLUDE_DIRECTORIES "${_IMPORT_PREFIX}/include"`
    + `IMPORTED_LOCATION_RELEASE "${_IMPORT_PREFIX}/lib/libginkgo_cuda.so"` 

### Other non related changes
+ Minor documentation fix
+ Reduce the amount of threads used in `gitlab-ci` for parallel make.
+ Speed up tools jobs such as `iwyu` and `clang-tidy` by introducing a new build template which does not run the tests, since that was already covered by the previous jobs. 

### Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/414

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Update and fix the create new algorithm script

This updates the `create_new_algorithm.sh` to HIP and provides new features.

+ Provide HIP support.
+ Allow file definitions in `TEMPLATE_FILES` to match multiple files
  + This allows to properly copy from jacobi which is split into multiple files
	  due to its compiling complexity.
  + This would also allow to have multiple test files for one functionality, and
	  in general make this script a little bit more future proof.
+ Manage the new `#include "common/.../xxx_kernels.hpp.inc"` pattern, by
  removing this line from the newly created files.
+ Improve the `todo_xxx.txt` output file by trying to provide a TODO list.


Closes: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/408
Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/420

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
Ensure non-zero diagonal when generating triangular matrices

The generator for random triangular matrices currently does not ensure that the triangular matrix has non-zero diagonal entries, which means the resulting matrices can be singular.

In the same fashion, the generation of the ParILU factors sparsity pattern relies on the input matrix containing all diagonal entries. If that is not the case, the resulting triangular factors don't have all diagonal entries and are thus singular.

This PR fixes this behavior by explicitly adding the diagonal entries (set to a random value or 1 in the test generator or 1 in ParILU) if not present.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/419

Add assertion for sparsity pattern equality

This PR adds the GKO_ASSERT_MTX_EQ_SPARSITY test assertion, which checks if the sparsity patterns of the two input matrices match.

This kind of assertion becomes interesting when we add more kernels that modify the sparsity pattern, like SpGeMM or the ParILUT kernels in general.

author: tcojean
message:
Minor release v1.1.1

Minor release v1.1.1

This version of Ginkgo provides a few fixes in Ginkgo's core routines. The
supported systems and requirements are unchanged from version 1.1.0.

### Fixes
+ Fix the `test_install` step with `HIP` ([#409](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/409)),
+ Improve Ginkgo's installation and fix the `test_install` step ([#406](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/406)),
+ Fix some documentation issues ([#406](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/406)),
+ Fix multiple code issues reported by sonarqube ([#406](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/406)),
+ Update the git-cmake-format repository ([#399](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/399)),
+ Improve the global update header script ([#390](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/390)),
+ Fix broken bounds checks ([#388](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/388)),
+ Fix CSR strategies and improve performance ([#379](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/379)),
+ Fix a small typo in the stencil examples ([#381](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/381)),
+ Fix ELL error on small matrices ([#375](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/375)),
+ Fix SellP read function ([#374](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/374)),
+ Add factorization support in `create_new_algorithm.sh`  ([#371](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/371))

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
Print error for incompatible HIP and CUDA settings

The Ginkgo benchmark module can include headers from CUDA and HIP simultaneously. When HIP is compiling for ROCm, this causes some redefinition errors. To avoid this scenario, we print an error message when CUDA and HIP with `HIP_PLATFORM=hcc` is used to compile the benchmarks.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/395
Closes https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/392

author: Tobias Ribizel
message:
Add basic SpGeMM kernel

This merge adds a sparse matrix - sparse matrix multiplication kernel for matrices in CSR format in the OMP and Reference executor.

It can be executed by calling apply on a CSR matrix with another CSR matrix of compatible size as parameter.

The implementation (reference and OMP) uses a hashmap to count the non-zero indices for each row and in a second sweep accumulates them. The resulting CSR matrix has unsorted column indices, but this might change if we move away from the hashmap-based accumulation.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/386

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge improve global update header script

This PR prevents the script `update_ginkgo_header.sh` from stopping
the building procedure. In case the script encounters an error, only
a `WARNING` is printed and the script is canceled.
Additionally, the script is now only called when `GINKGO_DEVEL_TOOLS`
is enabled since it is only useful for developers.


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/390

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Improve update_header script so it does not stop `make`

`update_ginkgo_header.sh` now no longer returns a non-zero exit code,
meaning it should no longer stop the `make` process when something
goes wrong or is not found.
Additionally, the script is now only called if `GINKGO_DEVEL_TOOLS` are
enabled since non-developer would not benefit or need it.

Merge fixes of CSR strategies

This PR contains the following fixes related to strategies:
- All conversions to CSR (except CSR to CSR) now conserve the original
  strategy (tests are included)
- Add exception throwing in case the `load_balance` strategy does not
  work because `srow` is empty

Other fixes in this PR:
- The macro`GKO_NOT_SUPPORTED` now throws an exception in contrast to
  just creating the exception
- An empty dense matrix can now be converted to CSR without crashing
  (test also added)


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/379

author: Pratik Nayak
message:
Merge adding a new permutation matrix format.

This PR adds a new permutation matrix format.

Additionally, it also adds a Permutable interface, which allows for LinOps to implement the row_permute, column_permute ,inverse_row_permute and inverse_column_permute functions. The apply method of the permutation matrix format, should automatically call these functions and there should be no need for the user to call these functions.

The Permutation format, holds two permutation arrays, the row_permutation and the col_permutation. It implements methods from EnableLinOp and hence will provide the apply methods. The apply methods will permute the given LinOp by calling the respective LinOp's Xrow_permute/Xcol_permute functions if the LinOp has a Permutable interface.

Related PR: #352 .

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Initial code for the HIP executor

This adds a basic HIP support with a new executor and the most common tools.

+ All objects other than matrix format, solvers and preconditioners are
	implemented.
+ The CMakeLists.txt saw some serious change in order to support HIP
	compilation.
+ All kernels for matrix format, solvers and preconditioners are set as not
	implemented. This needs to be updated as new PRs are created such as for ILU.
+ Several components from CUDA are not implemented, at least the ones
	relating to [cooperative groups which are still not supported by
	HIP.](https://rocm-documentation.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Programming_Guides/Kernel_language.html?highlight=cooperative#cooperative-groups-functions).
+ The current status is that all HIP compile, with all backends and both shared/static builds.
+ The code can be ran and all tests pass properly. Several problems had to be fixed for that:
   + Somehow, all gtest executions were empty (tests are not found) except when using a custom main function.
   + When running HIP, the kernel launches threw an exception.
   + Both of these problems are related to the following HIP issue, and a fix has been found: https://github.com/ROCm-Developer-Tools/HIP/issues/1029
+ The CI system had to be improved to add the new AMDCI system and merge build and test jobs.
+ Containers were upgraded in multiple ways.
+ There was an issue forcing make to be ran twice, which could be fixed thanks to the help of Pratik.  Read the PR for more details.


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/344

message:
Move the management of HIP_PLATFORM and CUDA_PATH to be environment variable only.

+ This is the only way to make HIP compilation work properly for both nvcc and
  hcc.
+ As configuration time has no impact on build time in terms of environment
  variable, the variables need to be exported otherwise configuration will use

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Initial code for the HIP executor.

+ All objects other than matrix format, solvers and preconditioners are
	implemented.
+ The CMakeLists.txt saw some serious change in order to support HIP
	compilation.
+ All kernels for matrix format, solvers and preconditioners are set as not
	implemented. This needs to be updated as new PRs are created such as for ILU.
+ Several components from CUDA are not implemented, at least the ones
	relating to [cooperative groups which are still not supported by
	HIP.](https://rocm-documentation.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Programming_Guides/Kernel_language.html?highlight=cooperative#cooperative-groups-functions).
+ The current status is that all HIP compile, but nothing has been tested yet.
+ There are missing pieces in the code at this point in time, which include:
	+ Implementing a way to access the `warpSize` variable and use it everywhere
	in HIP since [warp size cannot be assumed to be 32 in HIP
	code.](https://rocm-documentation.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Programming_Guides/Kernel_language.html?highlight=cooperative#warpsize).
	The warp size is actually 64 on AMD GPUs and 32 for Nvidia GPUs so far.
	+	Get the number of multiprocessors (Compute Units) [using the
	`hipDeviceProp_t` structure](https://rocm-developer-tools.github.io/HIP/structhipDeviceProp__t.html).
	+ Ensure compilation works and add HIP support to the CI system and all extra
	tools.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Release v1.1.0 for develop

The Ginkgo team is proud to announce the new minor release of Ginkgo version
1.1.0. This release brings several performance improvements, adds Windows support,
adds support for factorizations inside Ginkgo and a new ILU preconditioner
based on ParILU algorithm, among other things. For detailed information, check the respective issue.

Supported systems and requirements:
+ For all platforms, cmake 3.9+
+ Linux and MacOS
  + gcc: 5.3+, 6.3+, 7.3+, 8.1+
  + clang: 3.9+
  + Intel compiler: 2017+
  + Apple LLVM: 8.0+
  + CUDA module: CUDA 9.0+
+ Windows
  + MinGW and Cygwin: gcc 5.3+, 6.3+, 7.3+, 8.1+
  + Microsoft Visual Studio: VS 2017 15.7+
  + CUDA module: CUDA 9.0+, Microsoft Visual Studio
  + OpenMP module: MinGW or Cygwin.


The current known issues can be found in the [known issues
page](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/wiki/Known-Issues).


### Additions
+ Upper and lower triangular solvers ([#327](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/327), [#336](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/336), [#341](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/341), [#342](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/342)) 
+ New factorization support in Ginkgo, and addition of the ParILU
  algorithm ([#305](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/305), [#315](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/315), [#319](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/319), [#324](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/324))
+ New ILU preconditioner ([#348](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/348), [#353](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/353))
+ Windows MinGW and Cygwin support ([#347](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/347))
+ Windows Visual Studio support ([#351](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/351))
+ New example showing how to use ParILU as a preconditioner ([#358](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/358))
+ New example on using loggers for debugging ([#360](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/360))
+ Add two new 9pt and 27pt stencil examples ([#300](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/300), [#306](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/306))
+ Allow benchmarking CuSPARSE spmv formats through Ginkgo's benchmarks ([#303](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/303))
+ New benchmark for sparse matrix format conversions ([#312](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/312)[#317](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/317))
+ Add conversions between CSR and Hybrid formats ([#302](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/302), [#310](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/310))
+ Support for sorting rows in the CSR format by column idices ([#322](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/322))
+ Addition of a CUDA COO SpMM kernel for improved performance ([#345](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/345))
+ Addition of a LinOp to handle perturbations of the form (identity + scalar *
  basis * projector) ([#334](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/334))
+ New sparsity matrix representation format with Reference and OpenMP
  kernels ([#349](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/349), [#350](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/350))

### Fixes
+ Accelerate GMRES solver for CUDA executor ([#363](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/363))
+ Fix BiCGSTAB solver convergence ([#359](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/359))
+ Fix CGS logging by reporting the residual for every sub iteration ([#328](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/328))
+ Fix CSR,Dense->Sellp conversion's memory access violation ([#295](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/295))
+ Accelerate CSR->Ell,Hybrid conversions on CUDA ([#313](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/313), [#318](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/318))
+ Fixed slowdown of COO SpMV on OpenMP ([#340](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/340))
+ Fix gcc 6.4.0 internal compiler error ([#316](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/316))
+ Fix compilation issue on Apple clang++ 10 ([#322](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/322))
+ Make Ginkgo able to compile on Intel 2017 and above ([#337](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/337))
+ Make the benchmarks spmv/solver use the same matrix formats ([#366](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/366))
+ Fix self-written isfinite function ([#348](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/348))
+ Fix Jacobi issues shown by cuda-memcheck

### Tools and ecosystem improvements
+ Multiple improvements to the CI system and tools ([#296](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/296), [#311](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/311), [#365](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/365))
+ Multiple improvements to the Ginkgo containers ([#328](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/328), [#361](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/361))
+ Add sonarqube analysis to Ginkgo ([#304](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/304), [#308](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/308), [#309](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/309))
+ Add clang-tidy and iwyu support to Ginkgo ([#298](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/298))
+ Improve Ginkgo's support of xSDK M12 policy by adding the `TPL_` arguments
  to CMake ([#300](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/300))
+ Add support for the xSDK R7 policy ([#325](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/325))
+ Fix examples in html documentation ([#367](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/367))


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/370

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Improve the CI container setup

This PR updates the CI setup in accordance with what was previously in #307. This
allows to simplify #307 as well as multiple early benefits: testing ginkgo against
CUDA 10.1, gcc 9, clang 7 and 8. In addition, this allows the usage of the AMDCI
system as part of testing (CPU jobs, later AMD HIP ones also) which can help
reduce contention on the fineci system.

### Closes https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/323

### Overview
+ Test jobs are fusioned with build jobs, this removes the need for artifacts
  which Ginkgo overuses and can speedup the build process.
+ No CUDA containers are upgraded to gcc 9.1 and llvm 8
+ New CUDA 10.1 container and related jobs are introduced.
+ Use tags to allow using the AMDCI system and track between CUDA and CPU
  requirements.

### Unrelated change
+ Temporarily disable codecov since wrong coverage results are reported all of a sudden

### Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/365

author: tcojean
message:
Merge add an example to show how to debug performance with loggers

This PR adds an example mostly taken from the benchmarks to show how to use loggers to debug performance and residual convergence in Ginkgo.

The approach taken is to pass in as argument an optional file (and executor) which is the input matrix file in matrix market format.
In the code itself, at the beginning of the main functions, all important information for configuring the benchmark can be changed manually. The only other place the user may need to change is the preconditioner's settings when using a more complex one, in the solver factory declaration.

The benchmark has three segments:
1. warmup
2. timing
3. extract residual/operation timing information which can have significant overhead.


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/360

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge fix for ILU preconditioner and extend interface Preconditionable

This PR contains two changes:

### 1. Fix the ILU preconditioner
Each solver actually takes a `LinOpFactory` when a preconditioner
is expected, and not an already created one. Since the ILU
preconditioner had a custom Factory (not purely created through
macros), the Factory was not inheriting from `LinOpFactory`, making
it unusable as a preconditioner in any given solver.

Now, the Factory of ILU is created purely with macros, meaning it is
usable by others solvers, while losing the possibility to create it
with two distinct arguments (L and U). It is still possible to forward
both L and U to the preconditioner, but now, they must be contained in
a `Composition`.
Additionally, the ILU preconditioner can now be created by handing it
any matrix, which will internally be factorized with `ParIlu`
(also required, so others can properly use it as a preconditioner).

### 2. Extended the interface Preconditionable
Since some preconditioners can be quite expensive to build, it is now
possible to add an already generated preconditioner either to the
Factory (while calling `build()`), or directly to the solver.
To reduce code duplication, the implementation for setting and getting
the preconditioner is moved to the (formerly) interface
`Preconditionable` (which is now no longer an abstract class).


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/353

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Review update

- Make funktions in `Preconditionable` `virtual`
- Remove `generated_preconditioner` factory parameter in LowerTrs

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Move implementation into `Preconditionable`

Implementation of `get_preconditioner` and `set_preconditioner` are
moved from the solver to the class `Preconditionable`.
Both functions are now no longer `virtual` to allow for inlining.

Additionally, LowerTrs and UpperTrs no longer inherit from
`Preconditionable` since they do not use the preconditioner inside
the apply.

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Add `set_preconditioner` to the `Preconditionable` interface

`set_preconditioner` can be use to change the preconditioner of a
solver after it was already created & generated.
An error is thrown when the newly set preconditioner has wrong
dimensions.

Implementation of the `set_preconditioner` and tests (including the
throwing) are added for all respective solvers.

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Add `generated_preconditioner` to all solvers

This allows us to generate a preconditioner once and use it in multiple
solvers without the need to generate it again.
Providing a factory is still possible as it was.
However, if both a factory and a generated preconditioner is given,
the generated preconditioner is used, and the factory ignored.

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Make ILU usable as a preconditioner

All preconditioner must have a factory of type `LinOpFactory` in order
to get accepted as a preconditioner in any solver. This is now possible
with ILU (a test was added to ensure that).
However, as part of that adaptation, it is no longer possible to use
`generate` with both L and U separately. Now, either a matrix can be
passed, which will be factorized with ParIlu internally, or a
composition can be passed, consisting of both L and U (in that order).

author: Pratik Nayak
message:
Merge sparsity pattern matrix format addition.

This PR adds the sparsity pattern matrix format.

1. Adds the class definition and the core module.
2. Adds the core tests.

The main storage is in CSR as the main aim is to use it as an adjacency matrix. Therefore, it has a value array of length one which stores `(ValueType)(1.0)` by default but a value can be passed in by the user. It has a `row_ptrs` array and a `col_idxs` array similar to CSR. The read method reads in the user entered `value`(1.0 if not entered) and the write method writes the `value` in the matrix to the `MatrixData` tuple.

This matrix also has a method which will return the adjacency matrix from the sparsity pattern (which is mostly the removal of the diagonal elements) to satisfy the adjacency matrix requirements. This adjacency matrix has to be square.

Related PR #349.

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merged added ILU preconditioner

This PR adds an ILU preconditioner, which allows the customization of 
the Upper and the Lower solver separately through template arguments.
By default, solver::LowerTrs and solver::UpperTrs are used.

The solvers can be configured by setting the respective factory.
Default factories will be created if none are set by the user.
Both the max iteration and the reduction of the residual norm will be
set, if the chosen solver allows for it. Otherwise, no criterion is set.

Also, as part of this PR, the `get_l_factor` and `get_u_factor` now
return a `std::shared_ptr` instead of a plain pointer.


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/338

author: Pratik Nayak
message:
Merge Cuda kernels for Lower Triangular solver

This PR adds the CUDA kernels for the lower triangular solver.

+ Uses `csrsm2_analysis` and `csrsm2_solve` for CUDA versions>=9.2 and `csrsm_analysis` and `csrsm_solve` for CUDA versions<=9.1.
+ Multiple rhs for CUDA versions<=9.1 uses multiple loops each with a single rhs solve, and also needs a transposed RHS and solution vector because Ginkgo's and CUSPARSE's data structures are orthogonal.
+ This PR also changes the interface of the LowerTrs class to make it simpler. Now the Factory generate does not take the rhs vector as this is essentially a dummy vector needed during the generation of the solver for CUDA. The number of rhs is left as a factory parameter, but is not required to be specified as `csrsmX_analysis` does not use that either (It is left here for possible future changes in the CUSPARSE algorithms).

Related PR: #336

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge fixed slow COO SpMV for OpenMP

Fixed the slow COO SpMV for OpenMP by changing the loop order:
Now, first, we have the omp for-loop over the number of right hand
sides, followed by the loop over the matrix elements.
Previously, it was the other way around.

Some benchmark results can be seen in the related PR (link below).


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/340

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Changed loop order in OpenMP COO SpMV

Since the previous version contained race conditions, the order of the
for-loops was swapped (first over number of right hand sides, then
matrix values). For a single right hand side, it performs close to the
reference implementation, while for multiple right hand sides, it is
faster in most cases (at least in the ones I tested).

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Fixed slow COO SpMV for the OpenMP executor

Moved the `omp parallel for` to the most outer loop of the apply,
so it is parallelized over the matrix entries instead over the number
of right hand sides for every single matrix entry.

author: Yuhsiang Tsai
message:
Merge Perturbation LinOp

This PR implements the LinOp to handle Perturbation which has the form (Identity + scalar * basis * projector). The projector is stored in memory explicitly even if `projector` is conjugate transpose of `basis`
The main target of Perturbation is to present the Q from QR factorization.
i.e. `(I + c1 u1 u1*) ... (I + ck uk uk*)`
Related PR: #334

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Intel compilation

This makes Ginkgo work with Intel compilers >= 2017.

It is hard to make this work with Intel compiler 2016 because they [require very old GCC and Ubuntu versions](https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/intel-c-compiler-160-for-linux-release-notes-for-intel-parallel-studio-xe-2016#sysreq) for which Ginkgo has not been tested yet. Namely, GCC <= 5.1. In addition, creating GPU-enabled containers becomes harder.

Therefore, build and test jobs are added for all versions other than CUDA 9.0 with Intel compilers.

Summary:
+ By default, set `CMAKE_CUDA_HOST_COMPILER` to the C++ compiler.
+ Add container support for Intel compilers.
+ Fix several problems with Intel compilers 2018 and 2019.
+ Fix several bugs with Intel compiler 2017.
+ Update related READMEs.
+ Unrelated: remove `benchmark` and `examples` directories from coverage results as they somehow [got included recently, see numbers in red column](https://codecov.io/gh/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/tree/ef5c9c23aceaad22efb151ed5ecfd014aad3a186).


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/337

https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/intel-c-compiler-160-for-linux-release-notes-for-intel-parallel-studio-xe-2016
https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/intel-c-compiler-180-for-linux-release-notes-for-intel-parallel-studio-xe-2018

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Fix version bugs with Intel ICC 2017.

The main bug is that this compiler is not able to construct this object without
explicitly declaring this constructor for both the version class and the storage
scheme class. In addition the version class constructor should be constexpr so
that `version` becomes a literal type which can be returned by a constexpr
function.

Also fix a unique_ptr to const vs unique_ptr to non const cast problem which
Intel 2017 cannot solve, and another unique_ptr of gko::LinOp vs actual
MatrixType.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Fix CGS logging and update containers

This is a small PR which fixes a small problem with the way CGS is logged and updates the containers. Here are the description of the two commits:

### CGS logging
Report subiteration residuals through `iteration_complete` for CGS.

+ Previously, when running the CGS solver for 100 iterations only 50 residuals
would be reported because one loop does two iterations.
+ Currently, the same residual and solution vectors are reported twice as
these are computed only every two iterations (once per loop run).

### Container update
Update the containers with new functionalities.

+ Add Ubuntu 18.04 support for CUDA containers (cuda 9.2 and more supported only).
+ Correctly set the environment variables with CUDA paths
+ Add support for automake, pkg-config and libtool.
+ Add hwloc support and integrate a topology file of the machine. This has to be
done since hwloc has trouble finding CUDA devices inside the container.

### Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/328

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Update the containers with new functionalities.

+ Add Ubuntu 18.04 support for CUDA containers (cuda 9.2 and more supported only).
+ Correctly set the environment variables with CUDA paths
+ Add support for automake, pkg-config and libtool.
+ Add hwloc support and integrate a topology file of the machine. This has to be
done since hwloc has trouble finding CUDA devices inside the container.

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Report subiteration residuals through `iteration_complete` for CGS.

+ Previously, when running the CGS solver for 100 iterations only 50 residuals
would be reported because one loop does two iterations.
+ Currently, the same residual and solution vectors are reported twice as
these are computed only every two iterations (once per loop run).

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge Improved ParILU

This PR improves the parallelization capabilities of the ParIlu
kernels. The following changes were done:
- Instead of computing the NNZ of L and U, the `row_ptrs` of the CSR
  matrix are now computed in the first initialization kernel
- In ParILU, it is now checked if the `system_matrix` is symmetric
- Added (more) parallelization to both the new `initialize_row_ptrs_l_u`
  and `initialize_l_u` OpenMP implementations


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/319

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Improved ParIlu kernels: interface & implemtation

- Instead of just computing the nnz of L and U, the CSR `row_ptrs`
  are computed in the first kernel, allowing for better parallelization
- Now checking if the `system_matrix` given to factory is square
  (including a test that checks if it is working)
- Fixed errors in omp test (leading to a lower epsilon in comparison)

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Accelerate CSR->Ell,Hybrid conversions on CUDA

+ The previous grid dimensions for `initialize_zero_ell` were `stride *
  num_rows`, i.e. roughly the dense matrix dimension.
+ Using `max_nnz_per_row * num_rows` reduces significantly the amount of threads
  created which makes this kernel call more efficient (less useless thread
  creation).


Previous performance (see "To ELL" and "To Hybrid"):
![unfixed](https://i.postimg.cc/nVGwJycq/conversion-ratio-unfixed.png)


Current performance:
![fixed](https://i.postimg.cc/VNzd307q/conversion-ratio.png)

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/318

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Improve the conversions benchmarks

This adds some performance and result quality improvement to the
conversions benchmarks.

+ Move the construction of `matrix_to` in `convert_matrix` function. This allows
	to catch the related exceptions in a way similar to the other benchmarks.
+ Do not construct the `matrix_to` object until the use of `copy_from` in the
	warmup. This allows to catch non-existing conversions quickly (e.g.
        ELL->COO), without the overhead of loading big matrix data first.
+ Catch the `AllocationError` related exceptions for `matrix_from` and add a
	`completed: false` entry to the results on failure to instantiate a matrix
	from the data. This happens a lot when converting from `ELL` for example,
        which can take a lot of space.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/317

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Fix CSR->ELL conversion

And accelerate benchmarks.

### Conversion details
Fix a bug in CSR `max_nnz_per_row` computation.

+ The same `grid_dim` was used for the reduction and for the
  `calculate_nnz_per_row` kernel
+ The `grid_dim` was limited to maximum `default_block_size^2` elements.
+ For bigger matrices, the extracted `max_nnz_per_row` could be wrong, due to
  omitted values.

### Benchmark details
+ Move `matrix_from` to the external loop.
+ Benchmark directly into `matrix_to`.

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge Added Parallel ILU factorization

This PR adds a reference implementation of the Parallel ILU
factorization.
Additionally, a sort was added for CSR because in order for the current
ParILU to work, the CSR matrix must be sorted. In the reference
`CSR::sort` implementation, `std::sort` is used with a custom iterator.

Also, as part of this PR, the CI system is now restricted to using the
first GPU (device ID 0) only.


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/305

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Restrict the CI system to only use the 1st GPU

To prevent conflicts with other users on the CI system, we now restrict
it to only use the first GPU (device ID 0) for all tests.

Note: That also restricts the CUDA executor copy test to a single GPU,
      meaning data will be copied internally on a single GPU instead of
      across devices.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Fix TSAN and ASAN problems, improve sonarqube CI job

There were two problems for TSAN and ASAN:
1. As seen [here](
        https://gitlab.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo-public-ci/-/jobs/217839617), TSAN
	 failed in a seemingly random fashion. Two of the CUDA tests were getting
	 segfaults in the libasan calls, which caused the [main pipelines to fail](
        https://gitlab.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo-public-ci/pipelines/62624134).
         It seems that clang was one of the problems,  and making gcc use the
         flag `-static-libtsan` finished to fix it. A possible interpretation is that the
         dynamic library could suddenly not intercept some  important library calls
         (ptheard or malloc), which caused the problem. This is fixed with [this PR](
         https://gitlab.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo-public-ci/pipelines/63458321).
2. In general, there was always a reporting issue on the CDASH dashboard with
   `TSAN` and to a lesser extent `ASAN`. This problem can be seen [here](
	 https://my.cdash.org/viewDynamicAnalysis.php?buildid=1654329). All of the
	 problems are related to suppression parsing problems. Indeed, suppression
	 settings were set for Valgrind (and extra parameters also) in a global
	 fashion, which means that sanitizers which use a different suppression format
	 were failing to properly report the problem due to this. This is correctly
	 fixed with this PR (a lot of OpenMP problems are highlighted, maybe they are
	 real, maybe not):
	 https://my.cdash.org/viewDynamicAnalysis.php?buildid=1656004.


Other improvements:
+ the `sonarqube_cov` job which is run only for branches cannot have the same name
   as the one ran for the main branches, therefore the name is slightly changed (with an `_`).
+ the time it takes to run the sanitizer checks should be speedup a factor of around two,
   as I deactivated the tests for these which should not be needed.


Here is the pipeline which illustrates the change. The rest can be seen on the dashboard.
https://gitlab.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo-public-ci/pipelines/63458321
https://my.cdash.org/index.php?project=Ginkgo+Project&date=2019-05-28

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/311

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Really fix the Sonarqube problems...

Unlike originally thought, the commit which Gitlab-CI checks out from long
living branches such as develop linked to the last PR. In other words, the
previous version was always detecting an open PR on Github due to not
using a brand new commit which isn't tied to the last merged PR.

We can see that everything worked out previously, except that it detected the
closed PR for the develop branch analysis (use the raw log), therefore all the
information was added to the PR and not the develop branch.

In fact after further investigation, Github detects the merge commit as tied to
the PR (which was not expected at first).
Last develop commit:
22e4b07

Query link with Github-API shows the PR number:
https://api.github.com/search/issues?q=sha:22e4b07db7642b54e89c026372c9aae7554ff385

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Really fix the Sonarqube problems...

Unlike originally thought, the commit which Gitlab-CI checks out from long
living barnches such as `develop` is not a merge commit, but the last commit of
the last PR. In other words, the previous version was always detecting an open
PR on Github due to **not** using a brand new commit hash.
