author: tcojean
message:
Merge Add sonarqube capacities to Ginkgo.

This small PR adds sonarqube capacity to Ginkgo[1]  as part of the CI system.
The main goal is to have statistics (coverage, new bugs, etc) for each pull
request *before* merging into develop. This would allow to take care of many
coding problems as part of the PR process rather than after merging.

After this, I believe Ginkgo is fairly well covered in terms of tools for code static
and dynamic analysis. This is the last tool I wanted to add to Ginkgo.

+ Adapt the containers to bundle the sonar-scanner tool when found.
+ Add a CUDA job which launches the build-wrapper and sonar-scanner tools to
   scan the code and update all data online.
+ Put all coverage analysis on a per branch basis instead of only for the long
   living branches. This provides change metrics for branches before they are
   merged to develop.

[1]: https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=ginkgo-project_ginkgo

### Related PR
https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/304

### Visual changes to PR
1. There is a codecov report which shows up with a graph of coverage changes (here nothing changes, so it's all grey).
2. There are now 4 checks for each PR, the gitlab pipeline as usual, and after the `sonarqube_cov` step is processed, three extra checks are added. Two are regarding codecov, and the last one is the sonarqube "quality gate" which becomes red when either:
    1. There is bad coverage for the changes
    2. There is too many code duplication
    3. There are critical bugs (or many small ones) which are added as part of the PR.


Note that, for the sonarqube check to appear, a commit needs to happen to the branch (or the pipeline has to be ran), **after** the PR has been created on Github. If that is not the case, the analysis will nonetheless be available on sonarqube but will not appear here. In practice, I think there is always a couple of commits in the PR, as request for changes and fixes happen (at least for the big PRs which we want to have the sonarqube check).

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Add cusp benchmark

Move CuSPARSE benchmarking capacities to the `spmv` benchmark.

+ Add all `Cusp` benchmarks to a file `cuda_linops.hpp`,
+ Make all the `Cusp` classes be `gko::LinOp` for easy integration;
+ Control usage of these classes with the flag `HAS_CUDA`, given only when the
   benchmark is compiled with CUDA capacities;
+ Use [dynamic pointer cast](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/memory/shared_ptr/pointer_cast) of `std::shared_ptr<const gko::Executor>` to ensure
   the `Cusp` classes are called with a  `std::shared_ptr<const gko::CudaExecutor>`.
+ Remove the `spmv_comparison_cuda` benchmark.
+ Replace `CUDA_VERSION` with actual `CMAKE_CUDA_COMPILER_VERSION`.
+ Catch exceptions in benchmarks by const reference to get their actual type.
+ Add a function with specializations to manage the `cudaDataType_t` such as
   CUDA_R_64F.
+ Use pointer mode `HOST` for `cuspCsrEx` as it seems to be required.
+ Create CuSPARSE bindings for different precisions.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/303

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Create CuSPARSE bindings for different precisions.

+ Support IndexType int32
+ Support ValueType float, double, complex float and complex double.
+ Add a description of the CuSPARSE benchmarks in the spmv file.

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Put alpha and beta on the device since they are passed as pointers.

By default, Ginkgo handles use the `POINTER_MODE_DEVICE`, which means all
pointers should be allocated on the GPU. This pointer mode type has some
advantages as it means to implicit synchronizations with the CPU. For more
information see:
https://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/cublas/index.html#scalar-parameters.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Make Ginkgo better abide to the `M12` policy.

Support the `TPL` arguments for `GFLAGS`, `GTEST` and `RAPIDJSON` as
[explained in this document](http://dx.doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.4495133).

+ Move the `include` block of the extra CMake files to after the option
  declaration to ensure they are always set to the correct value.
+ Add a `ginkgo_add_tpl_target` to specifically add a target defined through the
  `TPL` arguments as an external library.
+ Modify `ginkgo_find_package` to support the `TPL` arguments.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/300

author: tcojean
message:
Merge support iwyu and clang-tidy

Add support for clang-tidy [1] and iwyu [2] tools.

### Overview
These tools allow to statically find potential programming issues and include
issues, respectively. They are able to find a lot of potential issues (both bugs
or style problems), so they are a useful addition for contributors. For now, no
specific configuration is included but it is possible to give a style file which
would control what we consider to be errors and what are not.

The use of the tools is controlled through the respective `GINKGO_WITH_CLANG_TIDY`
and `GINKGO_WITH_IWYU` variables. They are turned off by default, but their
availability is highlighted in the main `README.md`

[1]: https://clang.llvm.org/extra/clang-tidy/
[2]: https://include-what-you-use.org/

### Details
+ Fix some unrelated link problems in the main `README.md`.
+ The two programs are found through CMake `find_program`. This means that the path can be directly given for `iwyu` and `clang-tidy` through the variables `GINKGO_IWYU_PATH=/path/to/iwyu` and `GINKGO_CLANG_TIDY_PATH=/path/to/clang-tidy`, respectively.
+ Adapt containers to bundle a correct version of `iwyu` and `clang-tidy`. There are often problems with standard C headers for these tools and this can be fixed either through adding symlinks or through correct compilation. See [this link for more information](https://github.com/include-what-you-use/include-what-you-use/issues/679).
+ Add CI steps which gather the full `iwyu` and `clang-tidy` output


### Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/298

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Fix CI tests

Starting with commit 959f392f, tests are not properly ran.
That is due to not including several important CMake and
CTest files as artifact. Thanks Goran for noticing this.

See [this test output](https://gitlab.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo-public-ci/-/jobs/189319024) 
for an example of what was wrong. This is the original
commit/PR where this happened.

Changes: 
+ Add `CTestTestfile.cmake` to the artifacts
+ Add all main `.cmake` files to the artifacts
+ Add the libraries from `device_hooks` to the artifacts
+ Add a check to the `test` CI steps to fail when `0` tests are found.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Release 1.0.0

This is the first release of Ginkgo, version 1.0.0.

For more details about this release access the [release notes](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/releases/tag/v1.0.0).

### Content
+ The version number is updated to 1.0.0 everywhere;
+ In addition, the versions present in some example output is removed as they are not necessary for understanding what the output of each example looks like. This also prevents mistakes in version numbering in the future.
+ Improve examples documentation
+ Improve containers and CI configuration for documentation generation
+ Use `steady_clock` instead of `system_clock`.

### Extra information
+ The [full pipeline](https://gitlab.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo-public-ci/pipelines/56943511) was run for this branch.
+ The documentation was generated and is accessible [here](https://ginkgo-project.github.io/ginkgo/doc/release/1.0.0/).
+ The PDF version of the documentation is accessible [here](https://ginkgo-project.github.io/ginkgo/doc/pdf/release/1.0.0.pdf).
+ The CDash data can be accessed [here](https://my.cdash.org/index.php?project=Ginkgo+Project).
+ All coverage information is also available [here](https://codecov.io/gh/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/branch/release%2F1.0.0).

Closes https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/222
Closes https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/293
Related PR https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/294

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Custom logger example

The purpose of this example is to show the users how to customize Ginkgo by
adding a new logger, which is useful and more efficient for application specific
problems. This is also one of the most basic (and simple) ways of customizing
Ginkgo, therefore this is a good entry level example for customization.

This example simply prints a table of the recurrent residual norm against the
real residual norm. This example is documented as much as the`simple-solver`
example for the user's convenience.


Here are the additional extra changes:
+ Fixes all `build.sh` scripts which were seriously outdated and non working. 
+ Update the examples page documentation file
  + Remove a long and unneeded explanation on building Ginkgo manually 
     (the script should be used as an example) for that;
  + Add a customizing Ginkgo example list;
  + Add the custom_logger example to all relevant caterogies;
  + Break on 80 characters.


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/291

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Fix the Jacobi compilation time

This is an approach at fixing the Jacobi kernels compilation which aims at
sacrificing as little as possible the runtime performance and get down the
total compilation time for this file as much as possible, all the while having
a way to enable the full performance optimizations in an easy way.

This approach only touches the `generate` kernels in the end, and provides 
the full performance for the `apply` and other kernels as they are fast
enough to compile.

+ Split the Jacobi kernels into multiple files for parallel compilation and
   smaller code size.
+ Tone down some optimizations, namely use `#pragma unroll 1` in two
   places to prevent unrolling. This impacts the Jacobi `generate` kernels
   only.
+ Compile the kernels with only the block sizes `1, 2, 4, 8, 13, 16, 32` by
   default. With full optimizations, all block sizes (1 to 32) are complied.
+ Add a compilation flag for enabling back the full optimizations. This is
   controlled by the `GINKGO_JACOBI_FULL_OPTIMIZATIONS` define.

__NOTE:__ the generate kernel compilation with full optimizations still takes
above 30 minutes on my laptop for one architecture (52, Maxwell). Without the
optimizations enabled, it takes around 1:30 minutes.

When considering architecture 52, the compile time speedup is around 3.5, but when considering architecture 70, the compile time speedup is 15, and there is also enormous improvements when considering memory consumption.

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge Fixed `GKO_ENABLE_BUILD_METHOD` macro

The macro `GKO_ENABLE_BUILD_METHOD` now uses its parameter
`_factory_name` properly, so names other than `Factory` work with it as
originally intended.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/290

author: Terry Cojean
message: Put back the `__forceinline__` as this creates a performance problem.

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Fixed GKO_ENABLE_BUILD_METHOD macro

`GKO_ENABLE_BUILD_METHOD` takes an argument, which is supposed to be
the name of the factory class. However, this parameter was never used.
Instead, the name `Factory` was hard-coded, which worked because we
always use this name. However, it failed to compile when using a
different name.
Now, the argument is used properly, so names other than `Factory`
will also work.

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Fix the Jacobi compilation time.

This is an approach at fixing the Jacobi kernels compilation which aims at
sacrificing as little as possible the runtime performance and get down the total
compilation time for this file as much as possible, all the while having a way
to enable the full performance optimizations in an easy way.

This approach only touches the `generate` kernels in the end, and provides the
full performance for the `apply` and other kernels as they are fast enough to
compile.

+ Split the Jacobi kernels into multiple files for parallel compilation and
   smaller code size.
+ Tone down some optimizations, namely use `noinline` for one function and
   `#pragma unroll 1` in two places to prevent unrolling. This impacts the
   Jacobi `generate` kernels only.
+ Add a compilation flag for enabling back the full optimizations.

__NOTE:__ the generate kernel compilation with full optimizations still takes
above 30 minutes on my laptop for one architecture (Maxwell). Without the
optimizations enabled, it takes less than 3 minutes.

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge removed unused / unnecessary kernels

Removed not used (or replacable by `convert_to`) kernels `move_to_XXX`.
Also removed the not supported transpose functionality from Coo,
including deleting all related kernels.

The tests for Coo, Csr and Dense were also modified to comply with
our guidelines.


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/288

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Removed `move_to_XXX` kernels and `COO::transpose`

Removed unused `move_to_XXX` kernels from Dense and Csr. All calls to
`move_to(Mtx *)`, which previously used the mentioned kernels, now use
`convert_to_XXX` kernels.

Since we did not implement any transpose functionality in Coo, the
inheritance from `Transposable` and all related kernels were removed.

Additionally, the tests for Coo, Csr & Dense were modified as follows:
- Made include order compliant to guidelines
- Newlines in the tests are also according to guidelines
- Added MoveTo tests where they were not present
- Added tests for Dense conversions (used already generated variables)

The conversion from Dense to Hybrid with OpenMP was also slightly
improved.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Limit CI artifacts to what is absolutely required.

We seem to be reaching a problem with our artifacts size for one of our compilation mode for some PRs. In order to save space in general, this PR tries to upload as artifacts only what is really required (and useful). In details, that is the CMakeCache, the tests and the libraries.

See https://gitlab.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo-public-ci/-/jobs/188778903
Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/285

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge fix valgrind issues in Sellp and Csr matrices

The two issues detected by valgrind (and fixed by this PR) were in:
- `Sellp::write()`, where an `if` was based on an uninitialized value
- `Csr::automatical::process()`, where an index was out of bound when
  accessing an array

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/284

author: Terry Cojean
message: Limit CI artifacts to what is absolutely required (tests and libs).

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Fix valgrind warnings for CSR matrix

When testing what strategy should be used, the element at the index
[size] was accessed, causing an `illegal read` warning.
Now, access is limited to [size - 1].

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Fix for valgrind warnings for Sellp

In Sellp::write(), a value was read before checking if it is even inside
the size restrictions, leading to the valgrind warning:
"Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)"

The fix was simply moving the check before reading a value.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge fix circular dependencies

This PR fixes detected circular dependencies and improves the CI.

The approach used here is to keep the current system and enforce that no kernel module ever use any function with implementation in the core module. That was the case for two things in particular, the static variables of the `CudaExecutor` and the GMRES `solve_x` function. The `jacobi`  CUDA `advanced_apply` is borderline, I am somehow not able to make it throw an error. In fact, the CI is able to find some problem with the Jacobi (CUDA 9.2, GCC 7, Release build only), so it also requires fixing.

### Changes
+ Add a CI step to detect circular dependencies between Ginkgo modules.
+ GMRES used dense matrices and uses the preconditioner apply. These calls are
  moved to the core module
+ The static variables for the CudaExecutor were placed in the core module. They
  are moved to the Cuda module.
+ Fix the jacobi circular dependency using some code duplication.
   + All the `apply` kernels and the related kernel selector are duplicated with an
      alpha parameter in the calls
   + The advanced version scale by alpha inside the kernel themselves.
   + Use a new `multiply_vec_add` instead of `multiply_vec` which preserves the
      value in `x` by storing with addition.
+ Reduce the amount of CI jobs and integrate static builds.
  + For this, we vary more than one parameter at once. Here is the new overview:
  + core + gcc + debug + static
  + core + clang + release + shared
  + omp + gcc + release + shared
  + omp + clang + debug + static
  + all + gcc + cuda 9.0 + release + shared
  + all + clang + cuda 9.0 + debug + static
  + all + gcc + cuda 9.1 + release + static
  + all + clang + cuda 9.1 + debug + shared
  + all + gcc + cuda 9.2 + debug + shared
  + all + clang + cuda 9.2 + release + static
  + all + gcc + cuda 10.0 + debug + static
  + all + clang + cuda 10.0 + release + shared

### Closes https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/203
### Closes https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/278
### Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/278

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Update the license and provide contributing instructions

Our license did not use the standard text and format of a BSD 3-clause and github is not able to detect it.

This is a best effort at making our license compatible with Github. They [state in their documentation](https://help.github.com/en/articles/licensing-a-repository#detecting-a-license) that they use the tool `licensee` to detect the license. With the new version of the license, licensee detects that it is BSD-3 clause with 100% success (it did not detect anything before).

Other contributions are:
+ Change copyright ownership to `the Ginkgo authors` instead of the three universities only,
+ Update the README and related files for facilitating contributing to the project,
+ Simplify and update the `ABOUT-LICENSING.md` file a little.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/268

Merge removed extended globs in bash scripts

In an effort to support a wider range of shells (especially the bash
shell on macOS), all requested extended globs (requested via
`shopt -s`) like `globstar` and `extglob` were removed and any usage
of these extended globs replaced.

Additionally, all scripts which will be automatically executed when a
form of `make` is called were extended to include more debug
information if an error occurs.



Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/280

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
In `add_license.sh`, use `grep -F` for the beacon

`grep -F` prevents interpreting the given string as an expression
(treating `*`, `?` specially), which was necessary in the
`add_license.sh` because the beacon contains multiple `*`s and `<`.

Also added quotations for a `cd` in `update_ginkgo_header.sh`.

`dev_tools/scripts/update_ginkgo_header.sh` and
`dev_tools/scripts/add_license.sh`:
- `extglob` (`**`) by using `find` instead
- `globstar` with appropriate arguments for `find`

Additionally, made sure that commands that are used (like `find`,
`sort`, ...) are present and do not return an error.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge: update the third party packages to the latest releases

`gtest` and `gflags` are updated to their latest release. For `RapidJSON`, try to find a correct version as the last release is over two years old and there is a lot of recent pipeline failures.

This PR also ensures for our usage RapidJSON that there is no problem with some compilers when building benchmarks (i.e., building Ginkgo with `-DGINKGO_BUILD_BENCHMARKS=ON`). The problem was that on some compilers, no constructor can be recognized for the RapidJSON `GenericValue` object with a parameter of type `std::size_t`. The fix used is to add an explicit version of our main function `add_or_set_member` for `std::size_t` which uses a `static_cast` to `std::uint64_t`.

This is related to https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/270.
Associated pull request: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/274.

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge supporting CUDA Toolkit 10.1 with gcc

Because CUDA currently has a bug in their latest compiler, we 
altered our code slightly in order to circumvent this bug.
Only the method `Dense::create_with_config_of` was affected by it,
where we now de-reference the `other` pointer before calling 
member methods of it.
Now, Ginkgo builds and works with CUDA Toolkit 10.1 as well.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/271

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Better solution for CUDA 10.1 support

Instead of circumventing `Dense::create_with_config_of`, we can de-reference
`other` inside `Dense::create_with_config_of` instead of using the operator
`->`, which works with Toolkit 10.1.

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Made combination CUDA Toolkit 10.1 and GCC compile

CUDA Toolkit 10.1 does not allow a call to
`Dense::create_with_config_of` (it does not compile). In order to fix
that, `Dense::create` is directly called in the CUDA gmres solver.

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge support static build for Ginkgo with CUDA

For CUDA support when building Ginkgo as a static library, there
CMake requires to know that it needs to link against CUDA libraries.
This is done via the variable `CMAKE_CUDA_DEVICE_LINK_EXECUTABLE`,
which can be set by `enable_language(CUDA)`. We do that in the
`test_install`, while we forward the `CMAKE_CUDA_DEVICE_LINK_EXECUTABLE`
varialbe in Ginkgo from the `cuda` module.

Also some minor changes in the `test_install`:
- Fixed a typo in a `static_assert`
- Added the `Ir` solver to the test

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/276

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Allow Ginkgo to be build statically with CUDA

Building Ginkgo as a static library with CUDA requires the variable
`CMAKE_CUDA_DEVICE_LINK_EXECUTABLE` (set by `enable_language(CUDA)`)
in the parent `CMakeLists.txt`. This is now forwarded from the
CUDA subdirectory.

The `test_install` also requires this change, which is why
`enable_language(CUDA)` is also present there if it was build as static

Also did some minor changes in the `test_install.cpp`:
- Fixed a typo
- Added the Ir solver to the test

message:
Merge prevent executor mismatch

All functions in `Dense` now test if the executor of the data is the 
same as the executor of the matrix. If it is not, a temporary clone 
of the data is made and copied to the executor of the matrix. After 
the computation is done, it will be copied back to ensure consistency.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/260

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Fix CMake ALIAS IMPORTED target error

CMake allows aliasing from IMPORTED targets only in 3.11+, while
we want to support CMake 3.9+.
We used the aliasing to allow third party packages to be either
downloaded and build ourselves, or found through the `find_package`
command without any other changes in the code.

In order to do the same thing with 3.9+, the IMPORTED target is now
directly created with the expected name, which can also be a
namespaced target. Therefore, no ALIAS is necessary any more.

Merge pull request #237 from ginkgo-project/OmpBlockJacobi

This merge request adds OMP support for Block-Jacobi preconditioning. The implementation is block-parallel, i.e. the distinct blocks are handled in parallel, one thread assigned to each block. This generally renders better performance than using multiple threads per block.

author: Hartwig Anzt
message:
Merge pull request #236 from ginkgo-project/fix_memleaks

Overall, there was one real memory leak, multiple leftover CUDA memory which go away when using `cudaDeviceReset` and a few problems which should be suppressed.

Overall, all that's left are 5 memory whenever using CUDA which are really hard to track down as there is no information at all. I am also unsure whether they are related to us. `cuda-memcheck` does not seem to find anything.
### Changes

    * When array has no executor and is copied to, also inherit the deleter from the
      other array.

    * Add three new suppressions for `cuInit`, `cuDevicePrimaryCtxRetain` and
      `_dl_allocate_tls` (thread local storage allocation) in `pthread_create`.

    * Call `cudaDeviceReset()` when deleting a CudaExecutor.

    * Do not create a CudaExecutor with an invalid `id`. While the code is correct,
      it generates a lot of memory leaks due to CUDA failures.


### Fixes https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/152.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge pull request #204 from ginkgo-project/prefix_macros

Prefix all Ginkgo macros and unify their usages for better compatibility with other projects. Closes #184.

This is also required for xSDK compatibility (statement M9 [[1](https://github.com/ginkgo-project/xsdk-policy-compatibility/blob/master/ginkgo-policy-compatibility.md)]). This MR gives us full compatibility with M9. This is also a nice thing to have before the first release.

```
M9. Use a limited and well-defined symbol, macro, library, and include file name space.
```

### Description

* Every macro, public or private, gets a `GKO_` prefix.
* There are multiple reasons for prefixing private macros, among which:
    * Do not overwrite public macros by mistake,
    * Identify Ginkgo macros from external ones,
    * This is simpler for coding: always use a `GKO_` prefix, period.
* All `#undef` are removed from `.cpp` files as these macros do not impact other
      files. The only exception is the module related macro `GKO_HOOK_MODULE`.
* Some file guards did not use a `GKO_` prefix, this is now also fixed.

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Prefix all Ginkgo macros and unify their usages for better compatibility with other projects.

+ Required for xSDK compatibility (statement M9 [1]).
+ Every macro, public or private, gets a `GKO_` prefix.
+ There are multiple reasons for prefixing private macros, among which:
  + Do not overwrite public macros by mistake,
  + Identify Ginkgo macros from external ones,
	+ This is simpler for coding: always use a `GKO_` prefix, period.
+ All `#undef` are removed from `.cpp` files as these macros do not impact other
  files. The only exception is the module related macro.
+ Some file guards did not use a `GKO_` prefix, this is now also fixed.
+ There was an unreachable logging call (after a return), this is now fixed.

[1]: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/xsdk-policy-compatibility/blob/master/ginkgo-policy-compatibility.md

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge GMRES CUDA solver support

This pull request adds the implementation of CUDA kernels for the 
GMRES solver.

It also makes the following changes to the GMRES solver implementation 
and other GMRES kernels:
- `residual_norms` was renamed to `residual_norm_collection`
- `krylov_dim` is now of type `size_type` (instead of `int`)
- Calculation of `final_iter_nums` is moved to `step_1`


PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/194 (1st version)
    https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/235 (this PR)

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Fix memory leaks in Ginkgo.

+ When array has no executor and is copied to, also inherit the deleter from the
	other array.
+ Add three new suppressions for `cuInit`, `cuDevicePrimaryCtxRetain` and
	`_dl_allocate_tls` (thread local storage allocation) in `pthread_create`.
+ Call `cudaDeviceReset()` when deleting a CudaExecutor.
+ Do not create a CudaExecutor with an invalid `id`. While the code is correct,
	it generates a lot of memory leaks due to CUDA failures.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge CDash integration plus coverage and sanitizers support

Provide support in Ginkgo for Coverage and Sanitizers build and CDash.

* Add a CMake script which simplifies adding new build types to the project
* Use this script to provide three new build types:
    * COVERAGE: relies on gcov and the `--coverage` flag
    * ASAN: relies on the flag `-fsanitize=address`
    * TSAN: relies on the flag `-fsanitize=thread`
* Add one QoS_tools step to the CI system which runs 4 jobs, one for each of the new build types plus valgrind.
* Only run these steps for the public repository to remove long duplicate jobs.
* Update CI benchmarking which was outdated.
* Add configuration files to simplify using CTest and support CDash.
* Document these additions in the Readme.
* Put `Release` as the default build type.

PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/231

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Fix conflict beetwen Ginkgo and CMake's `CUDA_HOST_COMPILER` settings

Fix conflict beetwen Ginkgo and CMake's `CUDA_HOST_COMPILER` settings.

We used a flag to use the default compiler as CUDA's host compiler. This flag
conflicted with CMake's own `CMAKE_CUDA_HOST_COMPILER` flag. To solve the issue,
our flag is removed since CMake supports the flag since version 3.8 and
documents it in 3.10 (we currently use CMake 3.9).

See:
+ Kitware/CMake@489c52c
+ https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.10/variable/CMAKE_CUDA_HOST_COMPILER.html


Issue: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/71
PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/223

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Improve Ginkgo installation information

Improve Ginkgo installation information and related targets for better xSDK compatibility.

This PR is required for [xSDK installation policies](https://xsdk.info/policies).
```
12. After packages are configured, they can be compiled, installed and​ “smoke”​ ​
tested​ with​ the following​ commands: make ; [sudo] make install ; make test_install.

13. After​ an​ install​ the​ package​ should​ provide a machine-readable​ output to show​ ​
provenance, that is,​ what​ compilers​ were​ used​ and​ what​ libraries​ were​ linked​ with,​ ​
as well as other build configuration information​ if this information was also​ stored​ 
in the install directory somewhere, so that users with problems can send the​
information directly to developers.
```

It is also required to try to better comply with some xSDK recommended policies.
```
R5. Provide a mechanism to export ordered list of library dependencies.
R6. Document versions of packages that it works with or depends upon, 
preferably in machine-readable form.
```

The main changes include using macros to provide information when installing Ginkgo, provide a `make test_install`, support pkg-config and CPack and finally cleanup Ginkgo's PAPI dependencies.

### Changes summary
+ Add a short description to the Ginkgo package.
+ Add information gathering macros to populate the INTERFACE dependencies of
  Ginkgo. Also extract related GIT information automatically (current branch and
  commit).
+ Export a lot of information in the `GinkgoConfig.cmake` file. Informations
exported are:
		 1. Package information (name, version, description, etc)
		 2. Git related information if the repository supports git (branch, commit hash)
		 3. Compiler information (path, version, flags)
		 3. Ginkgo configuration information (all CMake parameters)
		 4. Ginkgo installation configuration (directories)
		 5. Important external libraries used by Ginkgo internally such as the CUDA
		   and OpenMP libraries
+ Change the `install_test` into test_install and add a `test_install` target
  which tests the Ginkgo installation. Note that this works only after calling
  `make install`.
+ Remove PAPI from Ginkgo's interface libraries as it should not be needed. Also
  uniformize the PAPI macro with the new naming scheme. 
+ Support pkg-config file generation. For this, information is extracted thanks
  to a macro by looking at Ginkgo macro target.
+ Add CPack support to facilitate creating releases of Ginkgo.


PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/220

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Improve Ginkgo installation information and related targets for better xSDK compatibility.

Details:
+ Add a short description to the Ginkgo package.
+ Add information gathering macros to populate the INTERFACE dependencies of
	Ginkgo. Also extract related GIT information automatically (current branch and
	commit).
+ Export a lot of information in the `GinkgoConfig.cmake` file. Informations
exported are:
		 1. Package information (name, version, description, etc)
		 2. Git related information if the repository supports git (branch, commit hash)
		 3. Compiler information (path, version, flags)
		 3. Ginkgo configuration information (all CMake parameters)
		 4. Ginkgo installation configuration (directories)
		 5. Important external libraries used by Ginkgo internally such as the CUDA
		   and OpenMP libraries
+ Change the `install_test` into test_install and add a `test_install` target
  which tests the Ginkgo installation. Note that this works only after calling
  `make install` (and properly setting the CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH if needed).
+ Remove PAPI from Ginkgo's interface libraries as it should not be needed. Also
  uniformize the PAPI macro with the new naming scheme.
+ Support pkg-config file generation. For this, information is extracted thanks
  to a macro by looking at Ginkgo macro target.
+ Add CPack support to facilitate creating releases of Ginkgo.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Improve the third party package management inside Ginkgo.

Improve the third party package management inside Ginkgo.

This PR is required to comply with xSDK policies M12 and M16.
```
M12.​ If a​ package imports softwar​e that is externally developed and maintained, 
then it must allow installing, building, and linking against an outside copy of that
software. Acceptable​ ways to accomplish this include (1) forsaking the internal
copied version and using an​ externally provided implementation or (2) changing
the file names and namespaces of all global​ symbols to allow the internal​ copy
and the external copy to coexist in the same downstream​ libraries​ and programs.

M16. The package must support production-quality installation compatible with
the xSDK install​ ​tool and​ xSDK metapackage.
```
After this PR, these policies should be satisfied for everything except the `git-cmake-format` tool, which is required for developer usage only. It should be acceptable to not provide a development ready version through Spack.

This is satisfied thanks to using the cmake `find_library` function before trying to add our own subdirectory version of the packages. This allows specifying which package to use thanks to the standard `-DCMAKE_PREFIX_PATH` option if the package is not installed globally, or by using the relevant package finder options, or by using the CMake package registry.

For the `CudaArchitectureSelector` tool, it is tentatively included before adding the relevant subdirectory. That means changing the `CMAKE_MODULE_PATH` allows finding it.


To also ensure that there are no weird interaction problems with other important packages such as `googletest`, `gflags` or `rapidjson`, the packages are linked against through the use of external targets instead of using the `add_subdirectory` command.

### Changes summary
+ Add a new section to the README describing how third party packages are used in Ginkgo
+ Add a new third party package model with the following priorities:
	+ Try to locate the package through `find_package`
	+ If the package is not found or the user requests it, use our version of the package
	+ This relies on the new helper macros `ginkgo_add_subdirectory` and `ginkgo_find_package`
+ Instead of including the packages in our project through `add_subdirectory`,
  prefere using targets. A macro `ginkgo_add_external_target` was created for
	this purpose.
+ Ensure the CMake version requirements is 3.9 for the better FindGTest
+ Always use modern CMake by declaring targets, either IMPORTED or INTERFACE
+ Replace the Benchmark setup of RapidJSON to use a target instead of header paths
+ Move the package helper files to the `cmake/` subdirectory to better represent its new
  central functionalities


PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/219

author: Terry Cojean

author: tcojean
message:
Merge pull request CMake Modernization

Modernize and improve Ginkgo's CMake settings. This is part of a series of changes to improve our CMake installation and ensure full compatibility with xSDK.

+ Slightly reorganize the main CMakeLists.txt,
+ Ensure 4 space alignment are used everywhere,
+ Prefer the specific `Ginkgo_SOURCE_DIR` and related variables as much as possible,
+ Use `target_include_directories` instead of the global `include_directories`,
+ Use `target_compile_features` instead of the global settings,
+ Move the header installation to the `ginkgo_install` function,
+ Use `target_sources` instead of the source variable,
+ Use `target_compile_options` instead of tweaking the `CMAKE_<LANG>_FLAGS`,
+ Use `target_compile_definitions` instead of the global `add_definitions`.
+ The script `create_new_algorithm.sh` has been updated to the new CMakeLists structure
+ The `enable_language(CUDA)` calls for the static build now seem unneeded and have been removed


PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/217
Related Issue: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/109

Merge pull request #216 from ginkgo-project/cmake_ginkgo_prefix

Add a `GINKGO_` prefix to all CMake variables and functions.

+ Use this prefix for all CMake functions or macros declared by Ginkgo
+ Use this prefix for all public variables declared by Ginkgo
+ The README was adapted to reflect the change
+ The CI file was adapted to reflect the change

This is also required for xSDK compatibility (statement M9 [[1]]). This MR gives us full compatibility with M9. This is also a nice thing to have before the first release.
```
M9. Use a limited and well-defined symbol, macro, library, and include file name space.
```

[1]: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/xsdk-policy-compatibility/blob/master/ginkgo-policy-compatibility.md

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge Building ginkgo as a static library

As part of this MR, the required CMake version is increased to 3.9
in order to change the linking to OpenMP to both suite modern CMake 
and work properly with an installed version of ginkgo.

For CUDA to work with an installed version, CMake currently requires 
the varialbe `CMAKE_CUDA_DEVICE_LINK_EXECUTABLE` to be set (see 
this currently open issue from CMake:
https://gitlab.kitware.com/cmake/cmake/issues/18614 ). 
This can be bypassed by using `enable_language(CUDA)` where ginkgo 
is used (also needs to be done at the top level of ginkgo, 
which is done in this PR). However, this also has to be done whenever 
ginkgo itself is used, which is why it also needs to be present in 
the `install_test` CMake file (in case ginkgo was built statically).

`README.md` contains now some information about building ginkgo 
statically.


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/214

Merge fix for SellP conversion

Fixed a mistake in calculating the slice offsets in the conversion from 
dense to sellp. The offset of slice n was previously just set to the 
length of slice n-1 but should have been set to the sum over the 
lengths of all previous slices.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/215

author: Fritz Goebel
message: In the conversion from dense to sellp, calculate_total_cols is called to find out how much memory has to be allocated. By just using the default slice size, this could not properly work for any other slice size. That's why calculate_total_cols needs to get the slice size as an argument.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Fix Intel Compilation issues on ForHLR2

This fix is required for ICC >= 18 on the ForHLR2 platform.

The problems are the following:
+ The pragma omp for with `collapse` did not work because the end boundaries were not explicitly `const`.
+ The usage of the temporary `ReferenceFactoryWrapper` class required an implicit conversion from `std::unique_ptr<gko::LinOpFactory>` to `std::shared_ptr<const gko::LinOpFactory>`, which seemed to fail. This is now done explicitly.

Closes Issue https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/issues/209 (for now).

author: tcojean
message:
Merge Add a GINKGO_VERBOSE_LEVEL option to CMake

Add a GINKGO_VERBOSE_LEVEL option to CMake. This allows picking the amount of messages Ginkgo should print.

This is required to ensure full compatibility with xSDK policy M11 [1].  Exceptions can be turned off with the `-fno-exceptions` compiler option.
```
M11. Have no hardwired print or IO statements that cannot be turned off.
```

Outputs from examples and benchmarks have not been guarded. There are two reasons for this:
1. Benchmarks and examples are accessory and can be removed,
2. The very purpose of these pieces of code is to produce some output, and tell the user what it is.

Description of the option:
+ 0 disables all messages
+ 1 only allows some very important messages (failure or unexpected behavior)
+ Can be extended in the future with more levels to allow for better user interaction.

[1]: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/xsdk-policy-compatibility/blob/master/ginkgo-policy-compatibility.md

Merge automatic generation of `ginkgo/ginkgo.hpp`

The script `dev_tools/scripts/update_ginkgo_header.sh` generates
or updates the public header file `include/ginkgo/ginkgo.hpp` to always
include all public header files
(all `*.hpp` files in `include/ginkgo/` are considered public headers).

The script is called at every `make` call to ensure all public header
changes are registered before building.


Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/195

Added script that updates or generates the `include/ginkgo/ginkgo.hpp` header
according to the files in `includes/ginkgo/`.
If nothing has changed, the header is not changed (including change and modify timestamps).
The script is called at every `make` call to ensure changes in `include/ginkgo`
are registered without the need to run `cmake` again.

author: tcojean
message:
Merge "Add release builds and tests to the CI"

This PR adds a few release builds and tests to the CI system. The purpose is to ensure that Ginkgo stays compatible with release builds, without adding too many new jobs. The builds added are the following:

+ No CUDA with latest GCC an Clang
+ CUDA 9.1, GCC 6 an Clang 4.0

An example can be seen here: https://gitlab.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo-public-ci/pipelines/43901609
This is related to https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/199

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Add an automatic way to figure out if PAPI SDE is available and instructions.

Requirements to use PAPI with Ginkgo:
1. Have access to papi-sde private repo, clone it
2. Install PAPI and activate the SDE component:
   + cd <path-to-papi>/src
   + ./configure --with-components=sde
   + make -j$(nproc)
   + (sudo) make install
3. Edit <path-to-papi>/src/components/sde/interface/papi_sde_interface.h
   and add: `extern "C" {}` around the whole function definitions
   to disable C++ name mangling
4. Copy the previously modified header to an include path in your system

author: Goran Flegar
message:
Merge fix for Jacobi precond. precision detection

Merge fix for Jacobi precond. precision detection

This PR fixes a bug that in some cases causes the adaptive block-Jacobi
preconditioner to wrongly detect the smallest eligible precision. It occurs if a
block becomes singluar after trying to reduce the precision.  In that case, the
inversion procedure (which is part of the condition number detection), will
silently fail, resulting in a wrongly calculated inverse and condition number
(meaning that the wrong precision will be selected).

The bug is fixed by propagating the information about the failure of the
inversion to the precision detection method, which now correctly marks the
precision as not eligible if the inversion failed.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/193

author: Goran Flegar

author: Goran Flegar
message:
Merge improved solver benchmark

This commit implements the following solver benchmark improvements:

-   the _generate_ step is timed separately from the _apply_ step
-   during the "slow run" that computes all the residuals, each Ginkgo
    kernel (more accurately: Operation) is timed separately
-   in addition to kernels, memory operations (allocation, copy, free)
    are also timed
-   the component logger is implemented in a way that correctly handles
    multiple nested operations (e.g. a kernel launching another kernel
    internally, or performing a memory allocation/free/copy) by
    subtracting the timing of the child operations from the parent's
    timing
-   preconditioner metadata is collected; for (adaptive) jacobi this
    includes the list of block sizes, condition numbers and precisions
    used for each block

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/191

message:
Merge Preconditionable interface

This commit adds a Preconditionable interface which allows querying if a
LinOp is something that can be preconditioned, and if it is, the
preconditioner can be obtained via the get_preconditioner() method.

This allows to get the preconditioner of a solver without knowing its
concrete class by trying to cast in to Preconditionable, instead of
having to try all the solvers (with all template parameters) in the
library.

A small bug in GMRES, so it no longer includes 2 instances of
EnableLogging (one explicitly, and one through EnableLinOp).

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/188

author: Goran Flegar
message:
Merge improved operation to kernel mapping

This commit improves the implementation of `GKO_REGISTER_OPERATION`:

### Overloaded kernel and kernel template support

`GKO_REGISTER_OPERATION` now natively supports overloaded kernels and
kernel templates, so there is no longer a need for workarounds such as:

```c++
template <typename... Ts>
struct Wrapper {
    GKO_REGISTER_OPERATION(foo, foo_kernel<Ts...>);
};

// usage
exec->run(Wrapper<ValueType, IndexType>::make_foo_operation(
            arguments...));
```

This code can now be replaced with:

```c++
GKO_REGISTER_OPERATION(foo, foo_kernel);

// usage
exec->run(make_foo(arguments...));
```

Such constructs have been replaced throughout the code.

Since overloads are supported, this also means that instead of having
separate names for kernels that do the same thing, but for different
parameters, it's possible to register just one overloaded kernel
instead. For example, the `simple_apply`, `advanced_apply` combination
can be replace with an overloaded `apply`:

Old:
```c++
GKO_REGISTER_OPERATION(simple_apply, simple_apply_kernel);
GKO_REGISTER_OPERATION(advanced_apply, advanced_apply_lernel);

// usage
exec->run(make_simple_apply_operation(b, x));
exec->run(make_advanced_apply_operation(alpha, b, beta, x));
```

New:
```c++
GKO_REGISTER_OPERATION(apply, apply_kernel);

// usage
exec->run(make_apply(b, x));
exec->run(make_apply(alpha, b, beta, x));
```

This change has **not** yet been changed done in the existing code.

### Simpler implementation of the parameter counter

In the new implementation the kernel call is no longer nested inside a
recursive implementation of the parameter counter. While these recursive
calls are optimized away by the compiler when built in the release mode,
they are still annoying when debugging, as the backtrace will list a
whole bunch of useless stack frames on the boundary between Ginkgo core
and the kernels (linear in the number of parameters of the kernel). In
the new implementation, there are always only two such stack frames.

### Shorter naming scheme

The previous implementation was generating an operation called
`<operation-name>_operation` and a helper function
`make_<operation-name>_operation`. Since that latter was a bit long and
redundant, it was now changed to simply `make_<operation-name>`.

### `get_name()` method

The `Operation` class got a new virtual method `get_name()` that can be
overridden to provide a custom name to operations - which can then be
used during logging to keep track of certain operations of interest. The
default behavior is to use the name demangling API to return the name of
the dynamic type of the operation. Operations created through
`GKO_REGISTER_OPERATION` override that behavior and use the name of the
kernel (2nd parameter of `GKO_REGISTER_OPERATION`) followed by a hash
(`#`), followed by the number of parameters passed to the operation. I
think this is a reasonable heuristic that should filter out most
operations, while avoiding long names returned by name demangling.

message:
Merge improved error messages

This PR improves the `what()` messages of `NotCompiled` and
`NotSupported` exceptions when they are generated using the
`NOT_COMPILED` and `NOT_SUPPORTED` macros.  `NOT_COMPILED` now properly
expands the `GKO_HOOK_MODULE` macro to the module in question so a
message like:

> feature XXX is part of the GKO_HOOK_MODULE module, which is not 
> compiled on this system

is replaced with:

> feature XXX is part of the reference module, which is not 
> compiled on this system

The messages generated by `NOT_SUPPORTED` now use the demangling API to
return the demangled name of the object in question.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/182

author: Thomas Grützmacher
message:
Merge correct installation location

This merge prevents name clashes with other libraries by installing
__public__ headers to `${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/include/ginkgo/`.  For
that, a separation is introduced between __public__ headers, which are
intended for other users, and __private__ headers, which are for
internal purposes and not designed to be visible to users.

Public headers are now stored in
`<ginkgo_project_directory>/include/ginkgo/` (and installed to the
previously mentioned `${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/include/ginkgo/` by `make
install`), while the private header / files remain at
`<ginkgo_project_directory>/{core,cuda,reference,omp}`.

A file is currently chosen to be a public header when all the following
criteria are met:

1.  It is/was inside `core/`
2.  The file ends with `.hpp`
3.  It is __NOT__ inside `core/synthesizer`
4.  It is __NOT__ inside `core/test`
5.  It does __NOT__ end with `_kernels.hpp`
6.  It is __NEITHER__ of the following header:
    -   `core/base/extended_float.hpp`
    -    `core/preconditioner/jacobi_utils.hpp`

Detailed list of updates:

- Moved the public files to the new location `include/ginkgo/` in the
  project folder
- Changed all includes to use `#include <ginkgo/core/[...]>` for the
  public header
- Removed all dependencies to private header from public header
- Added an install-test (folder `install_test`) to make sure all public header 
   are accessible after installation.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/183

author: Goran Flegar
message:
Merge Improved adaptive Jacobi precision detection

This PR extends the automatic precision detection in adaptive
block-Jacobi with all 6 supported types: `11,52`, `11,20`, `8,23`,
`11,4`, `8,7` and `5,10` (1).  Types reducing the original range of the
numbers are also checked for overflow and underflow by computing the
condition number of the rounded-down inverse, as described in
https://doi.org/10.1002/cpe.4460.

The precision detection favors accuracy (i.e. the number of digits
preserved when applying the reduced precision preconditioner, computed
as reported in the referenced paper), followed by the size (e.g. if a
32bit and a 16bit type both result in favorable accuracy, the 16bit type
will be chosen), followed by the number of range non-preserving
conversions, i.e. extra accuracy (e.g. if there are two 16bits types
that both achieve good enough accuracy, the one leaving more bits for
the significand will be chosen).  Concretely, the last type from list
(1) that achieves enough accuracy will be used.

Selection of the group-wide type was also improved slightly. In the
previous version, types of all blocks were chosen independently, and the
smallest common type (the smallest type that does not have more
preserving nor non-preserving precision reductions than any of the
individual types) of the entire group was used. Choosing the type this
way has some deficiencies. For example, a group consisting of two
blocks, one that can be stored in either `11,4` (precision_reduction(0,
2)), `8,7` (precision_reduction(1, 1)) or `5,10` (precision_reduction(2,
0)), and another that can only be stored in `11,4`. By using the
original procedure, the chosen types will be set to `5,10` for the first
block and `11,4` for the second one, so their common type is `11,52`
((precision_reduction(0, 2)). In reality, the entire group could be
stored as `11,4`.

Thus, the new procedure does not determine the final type of each block
individually. Instead, a set of all eligible types is determined for
each block, and the group type is determined as the best type (as
discussed in the 2nd paragraph) among the ones in the intersection of
all eligible sets of the group.  With this procedure, `11,4` is
correctly selected in the previous example. Since every supertype of an
eligible type is also eligible, the new procedure will always find a
better type than the previous one.

author: Goran Flegar
message:
Merge unified block-Jacobi preconditioner interface

This PR finally makes the interface of the block-Jacobi preconditioner
consistent with the rest of linear operators (e.g. by using the
automatically generated factory available through `Jacobi::Factory`
subtype). It also simplifies the interface and implementation by
removing the need for two types (`BlockJacobi` and
`AdaptiveBlockJacobi`), and replaces them with a single `Jacobi` type
that can handle both the normal and the adaptive version uniformly (the
two versions can still invoke separate kernels for higher performance,
but this is purely a concern of the kernel implementation).

Other minor bug fixes and feature extensions required to make this work
were also added, including the following:
*   the `precision_reduction` type that encodes runtime precision
    selection information, as discussed in the group last week
*   a useful piece of logic "if t is of type T, return it, otherwise try
    converting it to T and return the result" has been extracted into a
    separate function `copy_and_convert_to`. 
*   the implementation of the `Array` was extended to allow a default
    constructor that does not specify an executor, which can be bound
    later (this allows arrays to be used as factory parameters)
*   memory passing functions (give, lend, share, clone) were fixed to
    also work with unique pointers with custom deleters

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/167

-   it is no longer needed to manually create a combined criterion,
    just pass a list to solvers' `with_criteria` setter

author: Goran Flegar
message:
Merge improve storage scheme for block-Jacobi

This PR changes the block-Jacobi preconditioner storage scheme to use column-major instead of row-major order for the blocks. Benchmarks using a preliminary implementation of this storage scheme show that this slightly reduces the performance of the generate step (since now there is a non-coalesced data write due to the transposition), but the apply step becomes faster since now the matrix-vector product can be expressed in terms of a series of parallel AXPYs, instead of parallel dot-products which appear in the row-major version of the kernel. See the below referenced pull request for performance results.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/158

message:
Add logger transmission from the Factory to the created child. Also add a new lightweight logger which catches standard information once convergence has been reached.

Some minor fixes were also done. The logger transmission from the Factory to the
created child means that all products must also be `Loggable`, and this has been
done when it was not the case.
A major fix was changing the logging calls from inside the Updater to all the
`check` method calls which allow to transmit the logging calls to the
subcriterion when using the Combined criterion, among other uses.

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Multiple fixes according to Goran's remarks.

+ Fix `LinOpFactory`'s generate function to reuse `AbstractFactory`'s generate implementation
+ Fix `LinOp`'s logging by only using `PolymorphicObject`'s `log` and `add_logger` functions
+ Remove code redundance in the name demangling functions
+ Add better comments to all logger's events.
+ Add more parameters to both of the `criterion_check` events so that we do not depend on the updater
+ Add a warning in the `Record` class's documentation to warn about potential overheads

message: Improve format of name_demangling so that the *real type* of the object behind the pointer is printed.

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Update all logging examples.

Some other additions include:
+ Improve documentation of the loggers.
+ Remove the old events
+ Add group masks for convenience, which e.g. allow logging all executor events at once
+ Change the interaction between the Criterion class and the Updater in order to allow extraction of this information inside the loggers

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Add test for all new logging events in the Stream logger.

Including some other changes:
+ Change the order of parameters for polymorphic_object events, so that executor
	is *always* first,
+ Add the long list of events mask declaration due to static variable problems,
+ Add an operator<<  for stopping_status,
+ Add output parameter to polymorphic object create completed event,
+ Add from/to parameters to polymorphic object copy events,
+ Several improvements to Stream logger's printing format,
+ Add a macro ASSERT_STRING_CONTAINS using `str1.find(str2)` for all of Ginkgo's GTEST.

author: Goran Flegar
message:
Merge matrix market writer implementation

This merge commit adds functions for writing matrices to streams in matrix market format.
The current implementation supports both array and coordinate layouts, but does not support modifiers (symmetric, hermitian, etc.), and only the real and complex value types (integer and pattern are not supported).

The examples have also been modified to use these functions instead of writing out the vectors by hand.

Since the name mtx_reader doesn't make much sense if it can also write data the header has been renamed to mtx_io.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/98

author: Goran Flegar
message:
Merge improvement of CUDA implementation of ELL format

The CUDA implementation of ELL format is improved to avoid iterating over padding elements.
This can be viewed as an improvement of the ELLPACK-R format by Vazquez et al. (https://doi.org/10.1002/cpe.1658), so that it does not require an additional array.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/95

author: Goran Flegar
message:
Merge poisson solver example

This is an example that uses Ginkgo to solve a simple differential equation:

```
u : [0, 1] -> R
u''(x) = 6x
u(0) = 0
u(1) = 1
```

The functionality is equivalent to what is in the `3pt_stencil` example, but here Ginkgo's classes are used throughout the entire program, and not just in the linear system solution phase.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/80

author: Goran Flegar
message:
Merge automatic deployment of Doxygen documentation

This merge adds a CI job that automatically deploys Doxygen documentation generated from the latest version of the `develop` branch whenever `develop` is updated. The script takes care of the problem of multiple updates that could be caused by the public and private CI systems by creating the job if the `PUBLIC_CI_TAG` environment variable has been set (which is now true for the public CI system, but not for the private one).

The job uses the `ginkgo-bot` account to create a new commit on the `gh-pages` branch in the public repository, which has been set up to host the content of the branch on <https://ginkgo-project.github.io/ginkgo/doc/develop/>. The public wiki navigation bar has also been updated accordingly.

Note that the job has not yet been set up for the `master` branch, as we will probably want a different script for that: while we only want to host the newest version of the develop branch, we will most likely want to host documentation for all version of Ginkgo, not just the newest one, so we'll have to figure out which version are we currently building to deduce the correct path for the documentation.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/75

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Fix three bugs which we found yesterday with @gflegar. They concern the following software and version:

+ CMake GPU detection is buggy, for some reason if there is anything available
  from any CMake older than 3.8 available in your path, even with a recent
	CMake, the `#define __CUDACC_VER_MAJOR__` is not properly set.
+ GCC 5.3 has a compilation bug with `{}` constructor initialization in the
  `mock_free` example
+ nvcc 9.0.102 has a compilation bug with the flag
  --expt-relaxed-constexpr *and* the new additions from commit ed12b3df5d26

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Improve Ostream and ReturnObject Logger classes.

+ Make ReturnObject only manipulate LinOps, so the class is transparent and doesn't force Dense format nor templating
+ Improve `ReturnObject::LoggedData` by using `std:deque` for applies and residuals to access an history
+ Add templating to Ostream so that we can output any matrix type

author: Terry Cojean
message: Add documentation for `name_demangling`.

author: Terry Cojean
message:
Add name demangling functionality.

+ Add new files name_demangling{.hpp|.cpp}
+ Add conditionally defined `gko::name_demangling::get_full_function_name(...)`
   + When cxxabi.h itanium header file is found, demangle the name
	 + Otherwise, do not use demangling
	 + Try to return a name of the form "scope::function"
+ Implement the condition through the use of CMake

CMake allows one to define a header file (here in`include/config.hpp.in`)
which will conditionnally add `#define` when a macro of the form
`check_include_file_cxx` finds C++ a header file or not. See:
https://gitlab.kitware.com/cmake/community/wikis/doc/tutorials/How-To-Write-Platform-Checks

author: Goran Flegar
message:
Merge random matrix generator with condition number

This merge adds a `cond()` factory method to matrix_data which makes it possible to create random (dense) matrices with a specific condition number.

The matrix is generated by applying a series of Hausholder reflectors to a diagonal matrix with the requested condition number.

The merge also fixes a small issue with the range transpose operation, where the size of the transposed range was reported incorrectly.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/67

author: Goran Flegar
message:
Merge fix for atomic-related issues with custom value types

PR #57 introduced atomic operations for standard types, but not for custom value types, which causes compilation to fail for other value types (e.g. FloatX numbers).

This PR adds a dummy implementation of the general atomic_add (which just causes an assertion failure), so Ginkgo at least compiles with custom types, even though parts which use it do not work properly.

author: Goran Flegar
message:
Merge class hierarchy improvements

This PR is a major refactoring of Ginkgo's base classes, in preparation
for support of stopping criteria and loggers. It makes the interfaces of
all these classes more uniform by adding a PolymorphicObject base class
which provides a uniform interface for simple operations useful for all
such objects (linear operators, operator factories, and future loggers
and criteria). There are also additional improvements on factories and
linear operators, each described in their own section.

Related PR: https://github.com/ginkgo-project/ginkgo/pull/46

message:
Automatically detect GPU architecture flags

This PR adds an additional flag `CUDA_ARCH_OPTION` which can be used to
specify for which architectures the code can be compiled. The
architecture of installed GPUs can be automatically detected if the flag
is set to `Auto` (this is the default).

author: Goran Flegar
message:
Move Executor vtables to single link unit

The basic executor functionality has been moved from `ginkgo`
to `ginkgo_{cpu|gpu|reference}` modules.
Since both the dummy versions, as well as the real version of
these libraries have to compile the same basic method
implementations, these have been extracted into object libraries
"`ginkgo_{cpu|gpu|reference}_device`, which are then "baked" into the
corresponding dummy/real module at compile time.
